PETITION.TITLE: Community Services and Health Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senate assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate that the Government is about to introduce into the Senate, legislation changing health insurance. These changes will increase the cost of health insurance to members of employee based funds and will do nothing to help the elderly, as is being claimed. Big public funds will increase their surpluses by taking money from more efficient funds. People will be forced back onto Medi- care, which will not help to maintain private health insurance. Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate reject this legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Services and Health Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate assembled.
We, the undersigned, oppose changes to general medical practice contained in Community and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989, on the following grounds.

1. We oppose legislation which creates two classes of general practitioners and two classes of patients. Medicare is for all Australians. All Australians should receive the same Medicare rebates when consulting the doctor of their choice in any general practice or specialised area of general practice.

2. We oppose this legislation as it ignores the needs of women as patients and as doctors. It devalues Women's Health, and it will discourage women from, not only, becoming general practitioners, but entering medicine.

3. We oppose this legislation as it jeopardises the confidentiality of the patient-doctor consultation. Doctors on this Vocational Register must release patients' confidential clinical records for examination by the Independent Peer Review Organization and also information may be further released to other `relevant' authorities.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
The Senate will reject the proposed changes to general medical practice contained in the Community and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

This humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully draws the attention of the Senate to the Government's attack on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, which has severely affected the viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide the quality and quantity of services to which we as Australians have a right.

Your petitioners respectfully request the Senate to urge the Government to guarantee an adequately funded Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, so as to ensure the continued viability of neighbourhood pharmaceutical services through our local community pharmacies.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: End of War List
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned showeth that:
The members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in the Vietnam from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the Armed Forces.
After World War 2 and the Korean War the Australian Government approved an End of War List of Gallantry Medals for individual acts of bravery that were not rewarded during wartime.
The Whitlam Government refused to approve such an End of War List at the end of the Vietnam War.
Your humble petitioners pray that:
The Federal Government reverse the decision of the Whitlam Government and thus approve an End of War List for the Australian Armed Forces personnel that served in Vietnam.
Upon the approval of the End of War List, the case of the 2nd Lieutenant John Fraser, 3RAR be considered for the award of a posthumous military honour.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987-88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Brownhill (from eight citizens) and Panizza (from 193 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Home Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families.

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the Senate in Parliament assembled require the Hawke-Keating government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force most Australian home-seekers out of the housing market-and many Australians out of their homes-so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tasmania: VHF, UHF Transmission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned residents of Tasmania respectfully showeth:
That the mountainous terrain and geography of Tasmania makes VHF television transmissions the most suitable for the State;
That more than 30,000 Tasmanians will have to purchase new television receivers and new antennae if commercial television in the State is forced to change from the VHF to the UHF band;

Your petitioners therefore request that the requirement by the Department of Transport and Communications to force Tasmania's two commercial television stations to change from the VHF to the UHF band by 1993 be immediately rescinded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kangaroo 89 Joint Military Exercise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
From June to September 1989 Australia will host the Kangaroo '89 joint military exercises involving 28,000 Australian and United States troops from the air, navy, and land forces;
The exercise coincides with a massive increase in Australian military expenditure on frigates, submarines, helicopters, and joint military exercises;
Your Government's own defence paper states that Australia is without direct threat of invasion;
The Australian and New Zealand Governments are prepared to intervene militarily in the Asia Pacific region;
And believing that the Kangaroo '89 exercises are designed to:
Stimulate fear of invasion in the public;
Encourage acceptance of increasing Australian militarisation and continued dependence on the US alliance;
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in parliament assembled, should:
Cancel the Kangaroo '89 joint military exercise;
Allocate the $230 million due to be spent on the exercise to public health, housing, education, and other urgently needed social and welfare projects.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: KOALAS IN SOUTH EAST NEW SOUTH WALES FORESTS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, and follows a question I asked on 5 June in relation to koalas in Tantawangalo and Senator Cook's reply that investigations by the New South Wales Forestry Commission failed to find koalas in the area. Has the Minister seen a statutory declaration by a Mount Darragh property owner in which he says that he told forestry officers on 14 December 1988 and 14 April 1989 of the exact location of koalas in the Mount Darragh area? Have any of the areas identified to those forestry officers been logged, and if they have when did the logging commence and is it still continuing? Has the Minister seen a copy of the report of the independent consultants engaged by the New South Wales Forestry Commission referred to in his answer, and can he say whether the consultants visited the identified areas, and if so when and how long they spent in the areas? Finally, can the Minister say whether the independent consultants interviewed any of the land owners in the Mount Darragh area as part of their investigation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Dunn was kind enough to forewarn me of this question. The answer to the first part of the question, as to whether I have seen the statutory declaration, is yes. The other parts involve quite a detailed reply. I do not want in any sense to cut the ground from under Senator Dunn if she wants to ask me a supplementary question, but I wonder whether it might be appropriate for me to incorporate the detail of that reply in my answer now rather than going through all of those questions.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The reply read as follows-

1. In my reply to Question No. 933 I said on 5 June 1989 that the 1986 Environmental Impact Statement stated that ``in the Eden area koalas were most numerous in the Myrtle Mountain and Mount Darragh areas to the west and east of Tantawangalo respectively, and in the Bermagui State Forest''. I did not say that Myrtle Mountain and Mount Darragh were part of the Tantawangalo State Forest, as the honourable senator implies in her question. As I stated on 5 June, subsequent investigation by the NSW Forestry Commission and independent consultants have failed to find koalas in areas of Tantawangalo Forest scheduled for logging.

2. Yes. I am aware that the Mt Darragh property owner has advised various NSW and Commonwealth agencies of indications of presence of koalas near his property. In fact officers of my Department personally relayed details of the land owner's communication to the Regional Manager of the Eden forests and I understand that the matter was followed up by interview with the landowner and the conduct of surveys to ascertain whether koalas were present.

3. The areas in question, are in compartment 2453 of Tantawangalo State Forest. Part of this coupe has recently been logged and I have been advised that there were no signs before or after logging of the presence of koalas. I understand that the areas where the koalas are reported to have been seen are in a retained coupe which is not scheduled for logging for another 15 years.
4. As I have already said, I am advised that logging is not occurring in the areas where the property owner reported koalas.

5. I understand that the consultants' report was prepared for the New South Wales Government and has not been released publicly. I do not have a copy. Whether or not it will be released is for the New South Wales Government to decide.
6. I understand that the consultants visited the area and carried out three surveys during the day and at night, but found no koalas.
7. I am advised that the consultants did not interview the landowners but as I indicated earlier, the Forestry Commission met with the landowner concerned.
8. I did not state on 5 June that there were no koalas in the Tantawangalo State Forest. Rather, I indicated that I was not aware of any evidence of the presence of koalas.

The reports, which indicate that there may be some koalas at the south-eastern edge of Tantawangalo State Forest where it adjoins private property at Mt Darragh would not be inconsistent with the EIS which recognised that koalas are present in the Mt Darragh area.

I understand that the Forestry Commission is taking reasonable steps to ascertain whether there are any koalas in areas scheduled for logging. If the presence of koalas is definitely established in the area identified by the landowner I understand that the normal practice would be for that location not to be logged.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does the Minister agree with the Australian Tourism Research Institute estimates that the pilots dispute is costing the economy $36m a day? —I will not be replying to the last part of the question; it is a matter for the Cabinet to decide or not to decide at some future time. I had not seen the estimate of $36m a day. That comes out at something like $12 1/2 billion or $13 billion a year. It seems to me to be a bit fanciful, but I do not know on what basis it is supposed to have been calculated. I suppose that is the one that came from Sir Frank Moore, is it?
—Yes.

—I do know, of course, that Sir Frank Moore was the Chairman of the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation back in 1985. I am not sure whether he still holds that position. It was in that capacity that he hired Senator Stone to do some work for the Tourist Corporation prior to the 1985 National Taxation Summit. Perhaps the honourable senator might ask Senator Stone privately at some time whether he thinks $36m a day is a defensible figure. My own inclination is that it would not be. As for the rest of the question, a transcript that I have in front of me quotes the President of the Liberal Party, Mr Elliott, as saying that he does not support the pilots, and that he blames the centralised wage fixing system for the pilots dispute. He says that what the pilots should be doing is bargaining with the individual employers. I thought that that is what the pilots say they are doing now, and we can see what the consequences of it are.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister did not address what was the critical part of my question. I repeat it: Does the Minister agree with his colleague the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, Mr Holding, that the Government could not justify considering compensation for the airlines without compensating the real and more innocent victims of the tourism industry?
—I did answer that part of the question, Mr President. I said that those issues will or will not be determined by Cabinet at some time in the future.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Has the Minister seen reports that meat inspectors employed by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service intend to strike on Wednesday over new staffing arrangements? Are these reports correct? Can the Minister inform the Senate what effects are foreseen on meat industry operations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen those reports. In fact, the Meat Inspectors Association of Australia had announced that it was holding a nation-wide stoppage on Wednesday of next week; that it was holding a protest rally in front of Parliament House over staffing changes within the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service; and that it was launching a campaign about the quality of meat inspection in Australia. That was the case as of last week. On Friday of last week I caused a meeting to be held in my office between the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and the Meat Inspectors Association. At the end of the day the Meat Inspectors Association went back to consult its national executive. I have now been informed that the scheduled nation wide stoppage will not occur and that next Wednesday the Meat Inspectors Association will commence negotiations with the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service over their points of disagreement about the changes to meat inspection arrangements in Australia. As a consequence, the slaughtering loss for one day, nationwide, also will not occur.

ANSWER.PARA: I congratulate the Meat Inspectors Association on deferring its industrial action. I wish the Meat Inspectors Association and the Quarantine and Inspection Service well in pursuing their negotiations, since they have adopted a very sensible approach to resolving what is a complex issue. The issue concerns a change in inspection procedures which leads to a reduction in the number of meat inspectors. It is a very complex issue, one that is difficult for such an Association, which has a small membership, to deal with, but it has opted to negotiate on this matter. I am optimistic-without wanting to be too optimistic-about the prospects of this negotiation being successful. In matters of this nature it is often the case that the issues that organisations promote are not the causes of the industrial unrest. In fact, in our discussions last Friday, one of the causes of dissatisfaction that emerged was the issue of meat inspectors working on their own or in small groups spread around Australia and what they felt was their alienation from the central management of the Quarantine Service. I must say in defence of the Quarantine Service that it does a sterling job in keeping the lines of communication open, but, given the peculiar arrangements of this industry, it is an amazingly difficult job to do. What the two parties will now explore, as well as the issues that have come to symbolise the disaffection, will be ways in which a more participative style of management approach for meat inspectors can be introduced into the Quarantine Service.

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, there is no bargain basement price. I made it clear the other day that, if there were a shortfall, supplementation would be sought in the Additional Estimates. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I draw the Minister's attention to claims made in a recent article in the Bulletin magazine regarding the plan to expand the Woomera rocket range base in my home State of South Australia. The article claims that objections by tribal Aborigines to the war games plan will be overruled by the Federal Government, even though the people concerned were previously driven off their land to make way for British nuclear tests more than 30 years ago. The article goes on to say:

QUESTION.PARA: The Aborigines have been given no warnings of firing times or the types of weapons they might expect to see on their land.
Can the Minister inform the Senate of the accuracy of the article and of what plans the Government has to consult and assist the tribal Aborigines of Maralinga?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Foreman obviously has a very detailed knowledge of the Aboriginal people in the areas that might be affected at the Woomera rocket range. It is quite clear that he is certainly sensitive to the requirements of the Aboriginal people in a way which the Bulletin article was not. Certainly in relation to the issue of consultation with the traditional owners of the region, I am informed that the Department of Defence is presently in the process of negotiating a memorandum of understanding with the Maralinga people in relation to access to their lands. In particular, an agreement is being sought with the Maralinga Tjarutja, the statutory authority which manages the land in question. There was also a meeting and a presentation to the Aboriginal community at Oak Valley in May this year to discuss a draft agreement. Officers from the Premier's Department and the South Australian Department of Aboriginal Affairs were present. The traditional owners of the Pitjantjatjara lands may also be affected and, as I have said, they are also being consulted. It may be found to be appropriate for a similar memorandum of understanding to be negotiated with the Pitjantjatjara people. I believe that the Commonwealth and the State are obviously aware, as is Senator Foreman, of the sensitivity of the Aboriginal people in relation to this particular proposal and full consultation is being undertaken.

—My question is directed to you, Mr President. Can you tell the Senate whether there has been any delay in making arrangements for the first screening of the Parliamentary Education Office film about Parliament? If so, what is the nature of that delay? If the delay relates to the content of the film, what consultation do you envisage to ensure its earliest launch in a form acceptable to all?

—In reply to Senator McLean, I am pleased to inform all honourable senators that the film on the Parliament produced by Film Australia for the Parliamentary Education Office has been completed and has been given the approval of the Speaker and me for immediate screening in the theatrette. I am happy with the quality of the film and I am satisfied it provides a fair and equitable balance between all political parties and independents as well as between both Houses of this Parliament. It effectively explains the role, functions and procedures of the Parliament in an informative and interesting way. The film is to be released for general viewing in Parliament House this week and will shortly be available in VHS and Beta formats for distribution and marketing throughout Australia. I have received a proposal that all senators and members receive a complimentary copy from the Parliamentary Education Office and the Speaker and I will consider this matter later in the week. The only delay I am aware of in the first screening of the film for the public relates to the availability of a copy of the final film. As to the launch ceremony, the Speaker and I are still considering the format and cost of this event.

ANSWER.PARA: Whatever happens, Harlin has four new holders of quasi-equity, shown in this morning's table.
The article goes on to state:

It's a nice commentary on modern finance that none of this ``equity'' will actually result in any dilution of existing shareholders in Harlin, even though it will ultimately more than double Harlin's previous equity base of $622 million if it is all drawn down.

If that is correct, and I have no reason to believe it is not correct, that is in contrast to the 1c paid shares which Mr Elliott and other executives and directors of Elders IXL have in the past issued to themselves because those 1c paid shares subsequently attracted bonus shares, fully paid, with all the rights of all other shareholders, and thereby of course did dilute the equity in the company that was held by ordinary shareholders. In an article published on 26 June, Mr Terry McCrann, formerly of the Melbourne Age and now of the Melbourne Herald, went into this matter in some detail. He revealed that Mr Elliott, for example, had received some $22m worth of free shares in that way-free, that is, to him but at a cost to all the other shareholders in the company-on which he was picking up $1m tax free, that is, tax free because the dividends were fully franked tax free dividends. Mr McCrann also forecast that Mr Elliott would pick up a great deal more this year.

To return to Harlin, since the equity, or quasi-equity, as Chanticleer refers to it, is of a somewhat peculiar character, I suspect that Harlin will continue to meet the test for being an Australian company, but I will ask the Treasurer to check that out. In respect of the broader question of the dilution of ordinary shareholders' capital through management and directors granting themselves one cent paid shares, there is a contingent liability for the payment of the difference between the one cent and the market price at the day of issue, a contingent liability which would be called up if the director or executive subsequently resigned. It is also hinted-rather broadly, I would have thought-in Mr McCrann's article that it is however possible to avoid that contingent liability if the one cent paid shares are subsequently transferred to a company, and there are some indications that that sort of manoeuvre is envisaged by the present management of Elders as well, the reason for that being that once it is transferred to a company the company has an ongoing life which an individual does not.

In relation to the broader questions raised by this sort of `transaction', it has been suggested to me by a member of the Liberal Party who was concerned about these fiscal shenanigans-a different member of the Liberal Party, incidentally-that the most effective way to deal with this sort of fiscal shenanigan is through corporate law, and that is a point of view I will be putting to the Attorney-General.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Justice representing the Attorney-General. Has the Minister seen reports that the head of the Special Investigations Unit is very pleased with the cooperation he is getting from the communist Eastern bloc countries in providing war crimes evidence against migrants to Australia? Has Mr Greenwood concluded a number of agreements with these countries to provide prosecution but not defence evidence? In view of the fact that the alleged crimes took place nearly half a century ago in foreign countries quite outside the experience of the Australian legal system, will it not be a matter of very great difficulty to ensure a fair trial? Might not defendants require access to the countries from which they fled or migrated to establish contacts with potential defence witnesses and would not these defence witnesses need exit visas and some credible guarantee that they would not be punished if they gave defence evidence? If anyone ever does go to trial and if we are interested in the trial being fair, should not these matters have been dealt with in the agreements reached by Mr Greenwood? If suitable agreements cannot be reached, should not the whole idea be dropped because fair trials would be impossible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation under which the Special Investigations Unit is now proceeding in the gathering of evidence that might sustain certain allegations concerning the activities of persons resident in Australia during the Second World War and the whole question of the operation of that unit and the way in which it gathers evidence was very comprehensively examined by the Senate during the passage of that legislation. It led to the insertion into the legislation of various clauses which put beyond doubt the fair trial, which Senator Hamer seems to be questioning, of any person who is charged. There is within that parliament-sanctioned framework all the guarantees that the common law protections which attend a criminal trial will be provided to those who might find themselves defending a charge that they are indeed war criminals.

ANSWER.PARA: I have not read the articles Senator Hamer refers to. If Mr Greenwood indicated that he was pleased with the cooperation he had received from the authorities in one type of jurisdiction, I am sure he would not mean to exclude the cooperation that he has received from authorities in other jurisdictions around the world. Indeed, I am quite sure that the sort of evidence that he has been able to gather has been because of the cooperation of those in the communist countries to which Senator Hamer referred and those in democratic countries such as West Germany, the United States and Israel. Mr Greenwood, of course, in discharging his function as head of the Special Investigations Unit, has not pursued his investigations with a prejudiced frame of mind, but has sought not only the sort of evidence which might lead to an allegation being sustained but also exculpatory evidence-the sort of evidence which might indicate that an allegation was baseless, was perhaps even maliciously made, but certainly which might not be sustained. He has made it very clear in all his cooperative work with authorities overseas that he is looking, as I say, for both exculpatory evidence and that which leads to some assertion of blame. I believe that fair trials, and the gathering of evidence which might lead to the assembly of a package which Mr Greenwood can hand to the Director of Public Prosecutions for consideration, can be guaranteed, as was fully explained and considered by the Senate in its passage of this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Tate has totally missed the point of my question. I accept that Mr Greenwood is working with diligence and probably honesty in determining who should or should not possibly be charged, but the person charged will of course be presumed to be innocent. What I am asking is how a refugee from a communist country can expect to be able to acquire defence evidence-witnesses with exit visas and guarantees of safety-if he is charged in an Australian court 50 years after the event.

—It was made quite clear by the Senate-it was contained in the amendments which were accepted by the Parliament as a whole-that if the trial judge comes to the conclusion that an accused person cannot mount a defence in a fair and practical manner for the sorts of reasons that Senator Hamer outlined, the trial should not go ahead.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to various television, radio and print media reports of continuing harassment in South Africa this weekend of anti-apartheid demonstrators, black and white, by police using tear gas and water cannons loaded with purple dye? In view of the obvious indications that nothing has changed in that troubled country, and that suppression of freedom of movement and expression in that country is as prevalent as ever, does the Federal Government plan any further protest measures against South Africa, either directly or through the United Nations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great deal of television and press publicity has been given to the opposition in South Africa. The umbrella opposition grouping, the Mass Democratic Movement, launched a country-wide defiance campaign on 4 August with the expressed aim of forcing the South African Government to bring about changes to apartheid laws by peaceful means. The Mass Democratic Movement has developed a strategy of seeking access to whites-only institutions, including hospitals and schools. South African law and order administrators claim that the Mass Democratic Movement proposes to use violence. This has been denied by the MDM. I note that the only violence to have occurred so far has been as a result of the action of the South African police. Archbishop Tutu and other prominent church leaders are involved in the campaign. He was arrested on 2 September as he led a peaceful demonstration near Parliament House in Cape Town and was held for several hours. On the following day, 3 September, in Cape Town, we saw what has probably been the most violent police action in response to the peaceful defiance campaign, with police attacking protesters with whips and tear gas, and spraying them with purple dye.

ANSWER.PARA: The demonstrators were said to be trying to march to Parliament to protest against the national elections to be held on Wednesday, 6 September, elections which excluded South Africa's black majority. About 500 people were arrested, including Dr Allan Boesak, President of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches. Many people were reported to have been injured in the police action and many journalists, including Peter Cave, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation correspondent based in London, were also reported to have been arrested and tapes confiscated under emergency regulations. The Australian Government deplores the use of violence by the South African police in seeking to stop peaceful demonstrations and strongly urges the South African Government to order restraint on the police.The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade is asking our Embassy in Pretoria to convey this call by the Australian Government for such immediate restraint.

But in terms of restrictions imposed on the airlines, I am sure it has been said right from the beginning that the 30 per cent pay claims of the pilots cannot be countenanced by the Government and they should not be countenanced in the absence of very large productivity gains in the airlines. TALK.START.PARA: —I perhaps should preface my answer by saying that honourable senators should exercise some caution in accepting questions from pharmacists in view of the circumstances surrounding the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal case without finding out all the information and not just simply accepting what some pharmacists might say. ANSWER.PARA: Senator Knowles interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not a doctor and nor is Senator Knowles. Those who are qualified as doctors say there is no evidence to support the outrageous suggestion that Senator Knowles makes. The honourable senator is not a doctor and I would expect that she ought to withdraw that remark.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister is not addressing the question Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked. I ask that you ask him to address the question asked.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources. What levels of assistance have been given or commissioned to companies or governments involved in tropical forest clearing in Irian Jaya by way of technical and scientific information via the Commonwalth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation or other Commonwealth bodies, in particular joint venturer Asmus McLeans? Have export licences been issued for eucalypt, acacia or other Australian tree stock for the purpose of establishing plantations in southern Irian Jaya once Scott-Astra has cleared its 850,000-hectare tropical forest concession there? If not, will the export of Australian botanical stock for this purpose be subject to public environmental review? Will the Minister consider the application of sanctions against companies operating in or from Australia which are engaged in significant environmental destruction and social dislocation in this region in contravention of this Government's endorsement of sustainable resource use as contained in the world and national conservation strategies and in the Prime Minister's recent environment statement? Specifically, will sanctions be considered against the woodchip licence monopoly in Western Australia of McLean Consolidated Pty Ltd?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very long and complex question and there are several premises in it which are just wrong. To answer all of them would take me the best part of the rest of the afternoon. Let me answer the question as it unfolds, hopefully with a maximum of succinctness. The first thing was about levels of assistance. I point out to Senator Vallentine that the environment statement indicated that $20m over four years will be available under our foreign aid budget for environmentally sustainable projects, and that is an element of the aid package that I direct her attention to. However, at a Federal level no aid is being provided, I am advised, by any formal government agency to logging operations or trials or for the transmittal of genetic material with Indonesia. I have been advised-and this is anecdotal, I suppose-that there may be an involvement with the Department of Conservation and Land Management in Western Australia, which may be providing some bilateral assistance.

ANSWER.PARA: The same is true of the fact that McLean Consolidated has a logging concession in Irian Jaya of about 800,000 hectares. I am not sure whether the terms of production commitment entered into between that company and the Indonesian Government require it to supply any scientific or genetic material.

Having said that, the CSIRO has sold 63 seed lots at a cost of approximately $1,600 by way of research samples to companies operating in Indonesia, working with the Indonesian Government. It is a normal commercial operation for the CSIRO; it is the sort of thing it has been doing for 30 years. The species it has sold are acacia and eucalypt species. Those species are indigenous and not exotic to Irian Jaya. They were sold to a consulting firm doing work for the Indonesian Government on plantations as a possible basis for developing a feed stock for a pulp mill organised and managed by the Indonesian Government in consortia with private companies. The Indonesian firm that bought them is Scott-Astra and it is working in the consultancy with a Finnish consulting company.

Senator Vallentine also asked whether there was going to be a public environmental review. The answer to that is no. She asked about sanctions, and I think here there is a lot of wrong-headedness in her question. The national conservation strategy ought to be read and the Prime Minister's environmental statement ought to be read by Senator Vallentine when she frames these questions. There is a section in the Prime Minister's environmental statement about tropical rainforests which indicates that we are studying the impact on tropical rainforests and will shortly be making a statement about that and that I have been pursuing a tropical rainforests initiative in South East Asia. I have already had talks with the relevant Ministers in Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia and Vietnam. I had some discussions with Papua New Guinea before that, and that is a basis for trying to obtain a set of environmental conditions that would apply for tropical rainforest logging in those countries, similar to those conditions that apply in Australia.

I would counsel against any knee-jerk responses such as those implicit in the honourable senator's question by saying that in Indonesia I had a discussion with Dr Emil Salim, who is the Indonesian State Minister for Population Affairs and the Environment. He was also a commissioner on the World Commission on Environment and Development, what is commonly called the Brundtland Commission. He argued strongly-and I must say I have a great deal of sympathy and support for this point of view-that the biggest problem that Indonesia faces is that of slash-burn agriculture. It needs sustainable agriculture, and not logging operations.

But from an industry point of view he believes, as does the Indonesian forestry Minister, that the move by Japan just recently to lower the import duty on imported logs in their rawest form and increase the import duty on finished timber products militates against developing the economy. It does not enable downstream processing to emerge as an industrial option in those developing economies, thus keeping their economic growth down and meaning that they are always marginal economies unable to deal with the complex issues of forest management. Dr Salim has particularly made a call for that type of restriction to the main markets of rainforests to be changed to enable the economic growth which is necessary to underpin sound environmental management of those forests. So are we going to apply sanctions against McLean's? The answer to that is no, because I do not see any reason for it. I think the rest of the points have been answered.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to criticisms of the Government's education campaign to alert consumers and business to the implications of bankruptcy, as well as allegations that such information campaigns are a waste of money? Can the Minister indicate whether such criticisms are widespread or valid?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the criticisms. They have been particularly of the Government's bankruptcy video which was described in here last week by Senator Boswell as a `do it yourself kit'. The criticisms of the video are based on ignorance. They are based on no knowledge of the video or its contents or the reasons for it. They are based on a total insensitivity to the needs of the area. Thankfully, the criticisms are not widespread; they are not valid; they just come from members of the Opposition, and we know how isolated they are in the Australian community at the moment. Senator Boswell based some of his claims last week on the allegation that the amount of business bankruptcy has blown out under this Government. The basic fact about that is that in 1982-83 there were 2,385 business bankruptcies in the Australian community. The figures for the last financial year have recently come out and show that the number had decreased by almost 300, to 2,088. It should also be stated that over the last 12 months the number of bankruptcies overall decreased quite substantially on the previous financial year. So the premise of the allegation is totally wrong. The Government has addressed the question of overcommitment in a number of different ways. In 1982-83 the number of business bankruptcies in the Australian community was 2,385; in 1988-89 the figure had decreased by 300.
—And the next bit.
—I also went to the next bit and indicated that bankruptcies over the last financial year had decreased by 15.6 per cent.
—Over what period?

—Over the last financial year. The question was in fact about business bankruptcies. As I have said, the Government has addressed the question of overcommitment through education campaigns geared towards youth, through assistance to financial counsellors and through industry funded credit education foundations. But we also recognise that there are people who are overcommitted and people who will be bankrupt. The changes in bankruptcy administration have been geared very much towards that. The moratorium period, for instance, gives individuals a cooling off period before going to bankruptcy. Financial counsellors are then brought into place. The education package is vital as a way not of indicating to people how they go bankrupt but of explaining to them the implications of bankruptcy-implications that they need to know and which, quite often, government is asked by industry to bring to the attention of those who are about to go bankrupt. There is, therefore, a useful role for this sort of education package, which has been recognised by the community, industry and financial counsellors being part thereof.

ANSWER.PARA: Another part of the criticism went to the video itself. It should be placed on record at this stage that the video has been extremely well received and it has been recognised as an effective and useful video, to the extent that Film Australia has entered the video for several awards in the United States of America and one within Australia. It has been entered for the United States independent film and video festival. It has been entered in the intercommunications festival in Chicago. It has also been entered in the Australian training film and video competition. The video has also been sent to the United States Administration for it to use as a model. The idea of a video came, firstly, as I have said, from a request by industry and financial counselling groups. The Government has put it into effect as part of its overall comprehensive package in this area and it has been recognised by the wider community as useful. However, it seems to have been attacked by those opposite in a spirit of ignorance and insensitivity-something that we are used to.
