I understand that the airlines have received and are processing a large number of applications in response to those advertisements. I am not aware of the specific details of those applications, which are a matter for the airlines themselves to deal with.

ANSWER.PARA: On the same day, Senator Walters asked me how many stand-down notices had been given by Australian Airlines to those not able to do their job as a result of the pilots strike. I said at that time that I did not believe that there had been any stand-downs, and I undertook to seek further information. The answer is that there have been no stand-downs of Australian Airlines employees to date; various other arrangements have been put in place to avoid recourse to stand-down action and the airlines have advised employees that these arrangements will continue without prejudice until a further meeting on 6 September of this year.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator MacGibbon proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The damage inflicted on the tourist industry by the pilots' dispute and the Government's failure to resolve the situation.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have moved that, as a matter of public importance, the Senate should this afternoon debate `the damage inflicted on the Australian tourist industry by the pilots' dispute and the Government's failure to resolve the situation'. The damage that Australian tourism is suffering is severe and some of it, regrettably, is permanent. That damage is both to the tourist industry and to the Australian nation. The damage is already occurring, it is getting worse, and we are going to suffer the effects of that damage for years.

SPEECH.PARA: All of this is happening to a bankrupt country. During nearly seven years of Labor economic mismanagement we have seen taxes increase by 105 per cent, standards of living decline and, most tragically, the debt position of this country increase from about $32 billion to $35 billion, which it was in 1983 when this Government came to office, to more than $125 billion today. We are in no position to take this self-inflicted wound, which is purely a product of this Government's mismanagement of its industrial relations policy.

The tourist industry is our biggest overseas export earner. The reason why we are in this trouble is this Government's outdated, inappropriate and antediluvian industrial relations policies. It is this Government and no-one else which must accept the responsibility for the mess we are in. It has been in office for nearly seven years; it does not have the skills to cope with a modern, complex, industrialised society. It knew this was going to happen; everyone who took any interest in aviation matters knew that the airline pilots were planning a very serious, major strike this year. Even Senator Collins in the debate last week tabled with a great flourish some of the documentation that had been circulated by the pilots' union to members. The Government knew this was coming. It did nothing to intercept the course of events. It could have had a quiet word with its friend, Sir Peter Abeles; it could have had a word with Mr Strong. It could have said, `Look, there is trouble brewing. What about doing something to pre-empt this disaster which is going to befall us?', but it did nothing. Even worse, it did not even make a contingency plan. It sat on its hands and hoped it would not happen. Now that it has happened, we have not seen one constructive move from this Government to deal with this great national crisis that is upon us.

Why should this country suffer? Why should a country that is endowed with the human resources and the physical resources that Australia has, be mismanaged by the Australian Labor Party when we have seen so much progress this century? Honourable senators should cast their minds back to each of the four occasions during which the Labor Party has been in power. Under the Scullin Government we had the disaster of the Great Depression of 1929. We had the mismanagement, lack of direction and muddling through with a controlled economy which ensued during the war years, from 1940 onwards, until Labor was thrown out in 1949. What about the absolute chaos and the way in which society was stood on its head during the Whitlam years? The consequence of nearly seven years of the Hawke system of socialism has been this huge and crippling debt position which is around our neck, and will be around our neck for decades to come. Those situations should be contrasted with the great periods of growth in Australia under the Liberal-National Party Government. I refer to the golden age in the 1950s and the 1960s when Robert Menzies was running this country in accordance with Liberal principles that gave everyone a free go. The whole nation developed because economic growth--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us the growth rates. Don't lie to the Senate.

—The little dissembler should keep quiet; I have the call. Great growth took place because we had economic and individual freedoms. That should be contrasted with the four periods in this century when the Labor disaster has been foisted upon us.

SPEECH.PARA: I come back to this point: the present crisis is the fault of the Labor Government and no-one else. All we get from the Government by way of resolution is something about compensation. It is all very vague, there are no details at all, but it is talking about compensating the airlines. The Government happens to own one of the airlines. The other airline happens to be owned by one of the friends of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It is one thing to give support to private industry when it is being bullied by the trade union movement when only one small company is involved; it is one thing to give that company support with its great legal expenses when it is being victimised; it is quite a different matter to open the public purse to an airline that a government owns, and to one that enjoys a duopoly position, so that it can hold the market to ransom. I quote from a letter that was faxed to my office this morning from a Brisbane travel agent, dealing with this matter of compensation. It states in part:

The airlines are only a small and very privileged part of the tourist and travel industry. The airlines already enjoy enormous Government patronage denied to the rest of the Australian business community by having fixed prices and other commercial advantages which arise from protective legislation. The 21000 airlines employees are equally privileged by generous awards that reflect the airline duopoly. It would be a monstrous travesty of justice to maintain the wages of this privileged group of employees at the expense of the public when some 150000 other employees in the tourist and travel industry will be sacked by next Friday as a result of this dispute.
I think that puts the case very succinctly. The tourist industry is the biggest sufferer from this problem, not the airlines.

What are the damages that the tourist industry is suffering? In the first place, the tourism industry is a very big industry, and even the Government realises this. I have with me here copies of press releases by Mr Holding, the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories in the other place, and one from Senator Richardson, the Minister for Tourism amongst all his other duties, and in this press release Senator Richardson says:

In 1988 overseas visitors spent an estimated $1.6 billion on food, drink and accommodation, $800m on shopping, $320m on domestic air fares, $310m on trains, bus and car transport, $120m on organised tours, $120m on entertainment and $280m on other miscellaneous items. A further $1.6 billion was earnt by Qantas with international airfares.
Then Senator Richardson goes on to say-and these words must haunt him at the moment if he has any conscience:

At a time when many of our traditional exports face an uncertain future, tourism is expanding rapidly with the number overseas visitors increasing by more than 25 per cent in each of the last three years to a record 2.2 million in 1988.
Well, I have news for Senator Richardson. The numbers of tourists are not expanding at all; in fact they are contracting dramatically.

The tourism industry earned $6.5 billion in foreign exchange last year. But that is not the whole total of its earnings, because we have to add to that the domestic travellers within this country. In aggregate the tourist industry involves a turnover of something like $26 billion. There are over 480,000 employees in the tourist industry. It is the biggest private sector employer in this country. It might shock Senator Richardson to realise some of the responsibilities that he so negligently discharges. After the Public Service in Australia, the local government, State governments and Federal Government, it is the biggest employer. It is a very big employer of women and youth, two groups who are critically important in the Australian work force. There is something like $19 billion worth of work that is either under way or contracted for, and a great part of that $19 billion, which has great implications for Australian building and the economy in general, is now jeopardised by this strike, which the Government is doing absolutely nothing about.

Every sector of the Australian economy is affected by tourism. Just to give a trite example: every tourist in this country eats three eggs a day, so the impact of tourism on the economy is felt by the primary producers producing food, the manufacturers, the distributors and the service industry. The flow-on effects of any troubles in the tourist industry are absolutely horrendous. We have made a very big investment in tourism. In the last five years I do not know how many billions of dollars we have put in, but it has been a very great sum of money that the Australian economy has invested in developing not only hotels but the whole of the infrastructure related to tourism-the airports, the roads, and the service facilities supporting it. It is not a matter so much of saying it will not grow for a while. What is happening at the moment is that it is dying. We made this great investment in 1986, 1987 and 1988 prices. We are paying interest rates at the current time. This is the great difference between the tourist industries and the other great industries of Australia, where we made the investment generations ago in prices that were existing at the time and at interest rates that were about a third or a quarter of those that apply at present, and we have had the chance to amortise them. I am not suggesting that we take easily any setbacks in relation to the coal industry, or the steel industry or the wool industry. But at least setbacks there are more manageable to us than the position we have in the tourist industry, where we are extremely vulnerable. We require a daily throughput of tourists there just to stay alive.

What is happening at present? Well, the airlines have not stood anyone down yet, because the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) bully boys have seen to that. But the ACTU is not at all interested in what is going on in the hotel trade. I have had some figures come in to me this morning in my office concerning what is going on around my own State of Queensland. One of the largest hotels-I will not mention its name but probably most people here have stayed there-has advised me that it has lost 650 bed nights, that its customer occupancy has dropped from 80 per cent to 40 per cent, and that two conferences and 12 functions have been cancelled. Another one has had 12 conventions cancelled, some with 525 delegates, and that is just for the next two weeks. Another large hotel in Brisbane has lost 200 delegates, a sum of 310 rooms, in the last two weeks, and on it goes.

I had a report from north Queensland-and honourable senators would know very well that the north Queensland area, the Cairns area, is one of the brightest tourist spots in Australia-that as of Friday of last week 200 to 300 permanent staff and 600 to 800 casual staff had been stood down. Well might Senator Jones be worried about that. I can assure him that none of those people are going to vote for Labor in the coming election. Many other workers have been stood down or have been forced to take leave. The estimate for the Cairns area alone is that as of Friday last week the region had lost $20m in revenue. These are huge figures, multiplied across the nation.

The other thing about the tourism industry is that it has a very high small business component. For example, there are the small travel agencies. No travel agency in Australia has written a domestic airline ticket for the last three weeks. They have lost their 9 per cent sales commission. That is having a devastating effect. Some of them have already gone out of business. As far as we can determine, by the end of this week 150,000 workers in the industry will have been stood down. Hotel occupancy rates are down. The whole infrastructure supporting the tourist trade is grinding to a halt. That is just what is happening within this country. There are headlines about the dispute in the newspapers every day in Japan and in Europe. I was talking by phone to someone in the United Kingdom last week and was told that the strike here is getting much publicity in London.

As I said last week in a debate, if we are going to hold our position as a tourist destination we have to be predictable. If tourists come to Australia they have to know that they can fulfil their program as planned. They cannot be held to ransom by a socialist Labor Government which is failing to discharge its responsibilities. What are the consequences of the present disaster that we are locked into? One of my colleagues this morning suggested, only half jokingly, that we should refer it to the Natural Disasters Organisation. I do not think that is such a bad idea, but I would send the whole of the Cabinet along as well. The effects we are experiencing at the moment will take there to five years to overcome. It may well take 10 years and a very large advertising budget to work our way out of the mess.

What response have we had from the Government? All we have seen is the abuse of pilots by the Prime Minister and the dissemination of a degree of inaccurate information. I hark back to Mr Hawke's repeated statement that anyone can learn to fly an aeroplane-in seven hours. I invited Mr Hawke last week to table his log books in the Parliament. I am not aware whether he has done so, but I do not believe that Mr Hawke ever got to a stage where he went solo with the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) university squadron in Oxford.

TALK.START.PARA: —He got scrubbed.

—He got scrubbed, as Senator Lewis, an old pilot, says. As a person who has owned, for more than 20 years, the type of aeroplane that Mr Hawke claims to have flown, I think it highly unlikely that anyone could reach solo status in that sort of aeroplane within seven hours. In fact, it just does not happen. It is not the sort of aeroplane that is easy to get off the ground. The information Mr Hawke has put out about the number of hours that the pilots fly, how easy the job is and all the rest of it has not helped in any way at all to resolve the dispute. The responsibility of this mess lies with the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Collins said when he tabled the paper he tabled last week, the Government knew that there was a major, serious strike on this year. The Government made no plans to divert that eventuality; it let it happen. It has done nothing in the way of contingency planning for when such a problem arose. Even now it is not doing anything to resolve it.

We would fix the problem if we were in government, but we are not in government. The Government has the responsibility, and I hold very strongly to the principle of responsibility. We do not pay Senator Richardson as Minister and we do not pay the Prime Minister just to see their pretty faces in the paper or on the television set. We pay the Government members, irrespective of the person involved, for their responsibility in the office they hold. All we have seen from this Labor Government is a gross dereliction of duty. It has never accepted the responsibility incumbent on it-the Ministers and the Prime Minister of this country-to take the decisions and actions that the country demands. What has to happen is that the pilots have to get back to work, and that cannot happen unless the two parties meet-unless the employers and the employees come together. The employees are saying every day ad nauseam that they want to talk, but the Government is standing over them with a big stick and saying, `You will come back on your knees; you will come back within the 6 per cent wage guidelines'. It is completely overlooking the fact that the guidelines are broken every day with the connivance and conspiracy of this Government in all sorts of shaky deals around the country. Certainly there is a need for reform in this country's air transport system. We have a duopoly that provides no competition in the marketplace, and one of the essential points in the Liberal-National Party policy is that there be competition between those two airlines. We can do that by easing up the entry requirements for Australian companies to come into the transport pool, and if there are no Australian companies coming in then we can do what this Government is doing under duress-that is, allow interlining by overseas airlines between the capitals.

There have got to be changes. The pilots recognise they have to make changes; one only has to listen to what they are saying. Everyone recognises that change has to occur, except this Government. It is persisting with an archaic antediluvian system of centralised wage fixing; it is worshipping that shrine and will not allow the Australian community to get out of the mess we are in by allowing simple negotiations to take place between the two parties who are in dispute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have to say I am in agreement with at least part of Senator MacGibbon's matter of public importance. He speaks of the damage inflicted on the tourist industry by the pilots dispute, and obviously none of us can disagree with that. In fact, I would hope to spend some time today outlining just how bad and significant that damage is so that hopefully some of the pilots can begin to consider the consequences of their action. In listening to Senator MacGibbon once again one sees just how pathetic the Opposition is on the question of industrial relations. Its failure in seven years ever to come up with a wages policy has been documented time and time again by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). It is, of course, what so consistently knocks Opposition members out of the political ring.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, again, they demonstrate their complete failure to come to grips with industrial relations. There are a couple of ways to show that failure. I think most devastating for them is the fact that almost 60 per cent less average monthly working days are lost per 1,000 employees under this Government in comparison with its predecessor. That is a quite extraordinary figure, but it should not be surprising because this Government has not simply left employees and employers to sort out the industrial relations situation. In fact, I am surprised every time I hear Opposition spokesmen, including Senator MacGibbon, dare to refer to small business and damage that might be inflicted on it by disputes such as this, because this dispute is being fought under the rules which the Opposition would seek to impose on Australian industrial relations. That, of course, is the fundamental weakness of its position, an extraordinary weakness though it may be. But we see it illustrated perfectly in this dispute.

If one looks at the situation as it has developed over the last two to three weeks, it began with Senator Chaney taking a very hard line against the pilots. I must say that there were those of us who were encouraged by this beginning. But it did not take long for the Liberal Party in particular-one never worries about the members of the National Party on these things; ignorance is bliss for them, so they remain blinkered-to drift away from Senator Chaney's original hard line stance. It did not take long for succour and comfort to be offered to the pilots. That surprises no one at all on this side of the House. When you have no policy then all you can do is attempt to exploit the dispute for political gain. That is the only effort the Opposition can make on this question.

I want to agree with the Opposition. If it is about highlighting the damage that this dispute can do, I am all for it. Perhaps there will be some honour, some conscience, amongst pilots, and perhaps they will discover a reason to at least begin a process of sane resolution of disputes. But to simply say that the Government has failed to resolve the situation does not say very much at all. In fact, when I interjected on Senator MacGibbon and asked, `How would you solve it?', he could offer no explanation, no solution, at all. All that Senator Alston who is sitting next to Senator MacGibbon could do-and of course Senator Alston has a bit more to say about these things than Senator MacGibbon-was to offer the truly profound observation, `We would let the airlines talk to the pilots'.

The facts are, of course, that the airlines attempted to talk to the pilots for months. The difficulty with this group, and in particular with the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, was that it was hell-bent on a 30 per cent increase. It will always be the policy of the Opposition to stand back, to wimp out, to let the pilots win and have their 30 per cent increase. The Opposition experienced this situation and it still defends it. When we go back to 1981 or 1982, the facts were that it laid waste to the economy by stepping out of the ring and allowing employers and employees-as the Opposition says-to sort out their difficulties. The difficulty was that that meant wage rises like 14 per cent-14 per cent right across the economy. One cannot ever quarantine big increases, because of the flow-on. The flow-on went right though the economy two years in a row. It will remain the fundamental flaw in the excuse for a policy that the Opposition offers when it comes to industrial relations.

All the Opposition can do is opt out-wimp out-and nothing new is offered by Senator MacGibbon today. That of course, as I said, surprises none of us. But now, with the Opposition's policy in tatters, with this fairyland view of the world that in some way one can quarantine an increase for the pilots, all it can do is highlight the damage and then say that the Government has not resolved the situation. I might say, given that the Opposition believes the Government should not have a role in these things, that it should all be left to the parties, that is pretty surprising. But some assaults are pretty easy for the Opposition and we have seen plenty of them. I would have thought it better to concentrate on some of the positives and there have been plenty of those. At least this Government can say that it has created 1.5 million new jobs since it has been in office, that is five times the rate that the Opposition could ever manage.

I want to look a little more closely at this claim of the centralised wage fixing system in some way being at fault. I dare say that when one looks at the debate no one will take much notice of Senator MacGibbon. The Australian public never has before and there is no reason for it to change its ways in that respect. A lot of people in Australia do take notice of John Elliott, who is of course the President of the Liberal Party. He had some comments to make today on radio and I think they are worth looking at because, once again, they show the complete inability of the Liberal Party to understand the problem. I quote what he said today:
And the central wage fixing problem, the central wage fixing system in Australia is, as you can see it, starting to crumble-
this is not great English, but it is not my English-
get those increases without an improvement in productivity, then who's going to be next, the air controllers or the baggage people or who and it will flow on around Australia.

At least he got the problem right, in terms of the flow-on, but he does not understand the system as it exists. It has always been the Government's view that if they would simply pay attention to the structural efficiency principle, which of course emphasises productivity, then obviously that would have been the way to settle the dispute. Obviously, it would have been up to the pilots to go to the Industrial Relations Commission, seek negotiations with their employers and to come up with an agreement within the system which could-I am led to believe -have led to a substantial increase. It would have been nothing like 30 per cent, and that is, of course, right and proper. We cannot allow increases of that dimension. Nonetheless, that is what they could have expected had they opted to remain within the system. Instead of that, with this bloody-minded, determined attitude to hang on for a 30 per cent increase, in the end they put themselves outside the system. In spite of the hairy-chested and macho bleatings of some of their officials now, about how united they are, I think we will all see in the coming days that that unity cannot and will not remain.

In terms of the actual damage to the tourism industry, I do not want to be as bashful as Senator MacGibbon, because there are some areas of Australia that are suffering very badly indeed. There is no reason why we ought not to make some of those examples public. The Regent Hotel in Sydney is a good example; occupancy rates are down 30 per cent. It is said they are losing some quarter of a million dollars per day in revenue. Three conferences have been cancelled and it anticipates some staff stand-downs in the short term. At the Wrest Point Hotel and Casino in Hobart, occupancy rates are down 66 per cent, half the staff have been stood down, and $150,000 is being lost in revenue each week.

Australia-wide, the Southern Pacific Hotel Corporation is talking about international cancellations running at 30 per cent and its conference market being down by 50 per cent. If one turns to Queensland, Jupiter's Hotel Casino in Surfers Paradise says that occupancy is down from 70 per cent to 30 per cent. It is the domestic market that is most affected. These are, of course, horrific figures, and they demonstrate starkly just what happens when you have a bloody-minded attitude by the pilots carried on into this appalling strike.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you get out of the way. Why don't you stop the airlines--

—It is interesting that Senator Stone is interjecting so much, because Senator Stone has finally found a second union he could support. The only one he has ever supported before was the doctors'. He has always supported unions holding Australia to ransom. Here, today, he is prepared to support the pilots as well. What really worries me about that is not just that acknowledgment that if you are privileged you will get Senator Stone's support-everybody knew that was the case in the first place. The real worry is that Senator Stone is prepared to sit back and endorse horrific damage to the Australian economy which would flow from a capitulation to the pilots. I am a bit disappointed--
—Why don't you stop the airlines--

—I will tell Senator Stone something: if we give this 30 per cent increase across the board, there will not be an economy left. But the honourable senator does not care. All he is about is privilege and he will support it in any forum. This is another one.
—What do you think is happening to the Australian economy at present?
—Order! There are too many interjections.
—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I appreciate your support. Whenever I am looking for support, if my opposition is, Senator MacGibbon, I figure I can get by on my own.
—They will get you in the end, sonny.

—When damage to the industry is being considered, we should look at international visitors and the pain that is being inflicted upon them, and what that can mean to our future if this dispute is to become prolonged. Approximately 25,000 to 35,000 overseas visitors travel on domestic airlines each week. Of course, if they are to believe that that travel is not going to be possible, then the calculations will be coming in. Already we have had a group of German tourists who were in Central Australia; the next part of their trip was to be the Barrier Reef and that has had to be cancelled. Given that Germany is one of the markets the Australian Tourist Commission has entered pretty vigorously in the last 12 months to attempt to increase tourism, that is particularly disappointing.
—What excuse are you giving to these people?

—There is no excuse necessary for the Government in this matter, none whatsoever. All that the Government has done is make it very clear that it will not be stood over by bushrangers like the Pilots Federation.
—They will beat you in the end, sonny.

—They will not beat anybody, and when they do not, how is Senator MacGibbon going to look? He is used to looking silly; he will not mind. For the rest of us there is a principle that is important and that principle is to make sure that no-one caves in when it means a flow-on right through the Australian economy. We certainly will not be allowing that to happen now.
—Senator Richardson standing up for a principle-that's unique.
—Yes, unique.
—Unique? Heaven perish the thought.
—How do you recognise a principle, with your lack of experience?

—I am cut to the quick. Being accused by a couple of Queensland senators of not knowing a principle when I see one really is a case of the pot calling the kettle black. Stranger things have happened in this place, no doubt, and even stranger things will occur after this. Some areas of Australia have been especially disadvantaged and it is those that the Government sought to get some skeleton services in to fix up.
—Like Hamilton Island-a specially disadvantaged area.

—Again Senator Stone has not listened, as usual. If he had he would know that the Government, via the defence forces, has made planes available to the airlines. They are, of course, paying for the privilege. If they have planes on charter, then they will send them where they like. The Government has made particular efforts to make sure that the island State of Tasmania, as an example, has had some skeletal services--
—And Hamilton Island.

—I have just answered that. Senator Tambling was not listening; that is normal for him. Had he listened he would have been educated. God knows, if there is a senator in this place who needs some education, Senator Tambling is pretty close to being the best. I mentioned Tasmania because obviously, as an island State, it has faced particular difficulties, but remote regions have been looked at as well. As soon as the dispute began the Government made arrangements to look after places like Cocos (Keeling) Island and Christmas Island, where isolation is obviously a bigger problem than practically anywhere else.

SPEECH.PARA: When we get to the actual dispute and we wonder why the airlines or the Government should resist, let us look at the position of pilots. Over the past five years the average salary and related payments for pilots has risen by about 49 per cent while average weekly earnings have gone up 38 per cent. Again, pilots are in front of the game, well and truly. The current wage increase sought by the airline pilots would give them an increase substantially greater than the entire wage of the average Australian. Brian Grey has been looking at a new entrant joining aviation in Australia under the deregulation policy, that is, Compass Airlines. I note his comments. He has suggested that in the United States the pilots' counterparts work about twice the hours. I acknowledge that international comparisons are not always easy and one cannot take too much from them, but as an indication it would certainly suggest that there is room for a very substantial productivity dividend with Australia's pilots. That is what the airlines seek and that is obviously what the Government wants. The Opposition does not have any interest in productivity increases, only an interest in attempting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish. Read our policy.

—Everyone would like to read the Opposition's policies but no-one can find them. Whether we are looking at wages policies or tax policies, whatever the major policies are in the economy, we still have not heard from the Opposition. Nonetheless, its current leader has promised some policies this month. The breathless Australian public, that have waited so long, are all looking forward to it. But, of course, we also know that the Opposition has not agreed on it yet. With only a few weeks to go for the scheduled release of the major policies affecting the economy, it still does not have agreement. Opposition senators have the hide to come in here and talk about what should happen with the economy, when they cannot tell anyone in Australia what they would do about it.

SPEECH.PARA: When it comes to hide there is a better example of it than that. That anyone in the Opposition would walk in here and talk about tourism is pretty staggering. When the Hawke Government came to office the allocation for the Australian Tourist Commission under the last Fraser-Howard Budget was a miserable $10m; now, only seven years later, it is $40m. Senator Stone is good at these sorts of calculations. I wonder how many hundred per cent real increase in funds there has been for the Australian Tourist Commission and Australian tourism under the Hawke Government.

We can look at tourism numbers. When Fraser and Howard, the Liberal Party and the National Party, ruled Australia they never discovered tourism. It was not Australia's biggest export earner-nothing like it. It was never spoken about in Parliament; it was never mentioned. It was ignored totally for seven years. The Hawke Government put it on the map. The Hawke Government gave funds to develop tourism, to give it muscle. It made it what it is today. It made sure that around the globe people knew all about our tourism industry and made sure that tourism numbers grew substantially.

Senator MacGibbon read out some very impressive figures. I am glad he referred to them. For several years we had massive growth rates in Australian tourism. That came about because the Hawke Government gave the Australian Tourist Commission the necessary funds to spend around the world advertising Australia as a tourist destination. That is something the Liberal and National parties never even contemplated in government. There could not be a more staggering admission: an industry, now our biggest export earner, was discovered by Senator MacGibbon only today. It has been ignored totally by members of the Opposition, not just in their seven years in government, but in their seven years in opposition. The Opposition has no record on tourism; Opposition members have no right to speak for the tourism industry. By the way, the whole industry knows that: it does not look to the Opposition for support; it never has and it never will. The industry knows the damage that would be done to it if we gave in to the pilots. The whole of Australia knows just what would happen if we were to be so cowardly as to opt out of the system. Rather than that, we will stay in it; we will maintain it. It has served Australia well, and it will do so again in this particular dispute.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating the matter of public importance submitted to the Senate for discussion by the coalition Opposition, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The damage inflicted on the tourist industry by the pilots' dispute and the Government's failure to resolve the situation.

There can be no doubt that the damage to Australia's tourism industry caused by this dispute is immense. There have been a number of reports in the media since the beginning of the dispute. Our tourism industry operates on three levels: the international level, the national level and the local level. Combined, these three levels constitute a tourism industry worth billions of dollars.

On 8 May this year Senator Richardson was reported in the West Australian newspaper as having described international tourism as having overtaken coal as Australia's second biggest foreign exchange earner. He said that it had generated a massive $5.2 billion last year and that only wool brought in more foreign exchange earnings. The article stated:

``This confirms tourism's place as one of our major industries'', he said. ``We have only just begun to exploit its potential and already it is making an enormous contribution to our foreign exchange earnings.

``Each 20 per cent increase in international tourist expenditure results in a net improvement in Australia's balance of payments of around $235 million. Last year, overseas visitors spent an estimated $1.6 billion on food, drink and accommodation, $800 million on shopping, $320 for domestic air fares and $310 million on train, bus and car transport.

Senator Richardson also said that the visitors also paid about $120m for both organised tours and entertainment, with $280m going to miscellaneous items. As to the costs of this dispute on our industry, we read in the press that the Australian Tourist Commission expects it will result in losses of $600m over four months as overseas bookings slow. Most hotels are down by 60 per cent on their normal rates of occupancy, and several thousand workers in the tourism industry have been stood down.

In today's Australian Mr John Dart, the chief executive officer of the Australian Federation of Travel Agents, said the dispute was costing travel agents and tour operators around the country $10m a day and that more than 1,000 agency employees have been forced to take leave since the dispute began. Tourism at the national and local level provides income for a large number of people and, when pursued with intelligence and sensitivity, tourism also enhances protection and promotion of our history, the natural beauty of our landscapes and our flora and fauna. We Australians increasingly seek to take our holidays as tourists in our own country. We increasingly spend our hard-earned dollars here in Australia and therefore provide our fellow Australians with jobs. There has been a spin-off on a localised basis. For example, having been grounded in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) this weekend myself, and therefore unable to travel to Western Australia to fulfil electoral and family commitments, I took the opportunity to visit historic Berrima, which is in New South Wales, just some 150 kilometres from Canberra. I found this small town bustling with visitors on Saturday and Sunday and in fact it was impossible to stay overnight in any of the local hotels or motels. The local population, with their New South Wales and ACT numberplates, were certainly very well represented. This sort of picture is reproduced in small historic towns in all of our States-for example, Port Douglas in Queensland, and York, Northam and Toodyay in Western Australia.

But as Senator Richardson said, although all parts of Australia have suffered from damage to the tourism industry, it is the furthest flung parts which are bleeding the most. For example, one of the commitments which I was unable to undertake this weekend was to assist in the official opening of a new Aboriginal art gallery in Perth. The Creative Native art gallery is a classic example of the sort of damage that is being inflicted on the tourism industry. The number of tourists passing through that gallery is only some 30 per cent of the number that would have been expected at this time. The other problem is that 30 per cent of expected tourists have been spending very little, because as we all know tourists have also been involved in additional expenses caused by the pilots dispute. So there is no doubt at all about the damage inflicted on the tourist industry.

However, I would briefly like to refer to the point made by Senator MacGibbon and indeed by Senator Richardson, that there are other costs involved for the tourism industry which we also should take into consideration as we debate these matters. In a discussion paper put out in April of this year the Industries Assistance Commission described how tourism also uses resources, land, labour, capital and features of the natural environment, saying that we must also take the cost of the use of these resources into consideration when we look at the costs of tourism and the benefits that tourism brings us. As Senator MacGibbon remarked, the big boom in tourism has been described as finished but what we are looking to is a steady state, a steady as she goes tourism industry that we can all count on.

I would like at this stage to remind the Senate of two facts of life. One is that airline pilots can command higher salaries in countries other than Australia but greater productivity is for the most part demanded of them in those countries. A second fact of life is that one segment of the community cannot dig its heels in and make outrageous demands without the whole of the community being affected, so this dispute, by definition, affects us all. It affects the tourism industry-the tourism industry is bleeding-but it also affects us all and certainly will affect future wages policies.

In its motion the coalition Opposition lays the blame squarely on the Government's failure to resolve the situation. The Australian Democrats believe that is a somewhat simplistic analysis. Firstly, in 1987 the coalition Opposition objected strongly to the compliance provisions in the Willis Industrial Relations Bill and in fact effectively forced the Government to pull the Bill off the Notice Paper. Secondly, what we have in action is a preview of the model that would prevail if the coalition Opposition were itself in government.

—What needs to be realised is that a dispute can end only when relevant parties come to the table to talk. There must be a resolution sooner or later. Neither inflammatory statements by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) nor seeking to make political mileage can resolve this situation. No dispute is resolved other than at the table and once heels are dug in it is very difficult without the assistance of an arbitrator. In fact, how little we have moved forward in industrial relations in some 80 years. I remind the Senate of the play by John Galsworthy called Strife first published in 1909. This play is the archetypal depiction of a strike in which the two protagonists are intransigent. Each brings the other to its knees and of course the real victims are the innocent bystanders. The strike in this play takes place in the Trenartha tin plate works. There are finally no winners.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a battle of wills between the chairman of the board, John Anthony, and the leader of the striking workers, David Roberts. In this particular case the workers refused the conditions set by the unions. Finally both were brought to the table. The leader of the workers was finally brought there by his own workers after they had bled and bled. Likewise the chairman of the board was brought there by the shareholders who found themselves in a similar situation, and the final resolution was that the workers accepted the conditions set by the unions in the first place. I hope it will not come to that situation where we have the whole of the country bleeding to such an extent that finally the protagonists are forced to the table with nothing to be gained at the end. But this is the danger when proper negotiations are not followed through, when proper arbitration policies are not followed and are not supported by the Parliament and by the Government. Where we have no collective bargaining then it is very difficult to see when we can come to a result and certainly it appears that no collective bargaining is possible at this stage. The Commission itself has been abandoned; the pilots have resigned. So only individual bargaining is possible, which is, of course, the Opposition's policy.

We have got division, we have got chaos. In the meantime the tourist industry bleeds which means that all of us bleed. Some of us bleed now, but all of us bleed later if it carries on. We saw in today's newspapers a full page advertisement put out by the Australian Tourism Industry Association Ltd where it sought to prevent any parties to the current pilots dispute taking any action to prolong the dispute, interfere with genuine efforts to resolve it or extend its scope. Certainly those are admirable objectives, and I am sure that everybody here would endorse those objectives. But it is incredible to see how gaoling the pilots could actually achieve that. In fact the situation is very well summed up in a cartoon which appears in today's Australian newspaper. Here we see a jet plane marked `Tourism Industry'. It is on fire; all the engines are on fire; there is nobody in the pilot's seat. We have in the plane Mr Hawke actually throwing the last pilot overboard so that the aeroplane marked `Tourism Industry' is going to do nothing other than crash and save nobody.

The damage is certainly here for all of us to see. It is estimated that the tourism industry, Australia's largest export earning industry, is losing about $100m a month and that losses could rise to $180m a month by December. Mr Holding, the Minister, has said the strike has been as damaging as, if not more damaging than, a natural disaster. We have a failure to find a resolution to the situation-a failure by the Government, by the pilots and their association, by the airlines, by the Opposition, by this Parliament as a whole. Certainly, as this debate continues the Australian Democrats look forward to further contributions by the coalition Opposition to find out what are its positive suggestions.

Added to this is the cost associated with selling on mainland markets because the growers have physically to drive flowers from Devonport to Launceston or Hobart daily. The second part of this matter of public importance relates to the Government's failure to resolve the situation. Previous speakers have covered this very thoroughly and I intend to mention it again relatively briefly. The reason we are so particularly concerned about the Government's failure to resolve the dispute is that the Government aggravated the situation in the first place and pushed the parties into their corners. There is no getting away from it: it was the Prime Minister's inflammatory statements which pushed the parties into their corners, which are keeping them apart and which are physically preventing the employers and the employees from talking together. Why will the Government not allow the pilots and their employers to talk? Who is paying for that pig-headedness? It is the little people all over Australia. It is my Tasmanian constituents who are trying to travel-to travel as tourists or as business people, as family members separated by the tyranny of Bass Strait. It is the 91-year-old lady I am trying to help who comes from Tasmania and cannot get back from Brisbane. She is stranded and it is not suitable to put her on a bus at her age. These are the people who are paying for the Prime Minister's pig-headedness. These are the people who will not get any compensation even if it is handed out to the airlines. In fact, if compensation is paid to the airlines it will only prolong the agony for these little people and these little businesses. The Government is in a position to take action. It even had warnings earlier this year from the Industries Assistance Commission as to what should be being done, and I draw attention to the IAC draft report on travel and tourism. I will quote quickly, in the brief time left to me, from that report:

What is needed in the aviation industry, in the interests of tourism and the economy generally, is effective competition. The regulations governing the Australian aviation industry serve to limit competition and this imposes an unnecessary cost on travellers and other tourism related industries. Maximum efficiency requires . . . fully-integrated domestic and international networks.
Going on to talk about domestic aviation, the report said:

The two airlines agreement expires in 1990 . . . but for real reform there must be scope for effective competition. The arrangements act as a significant deterrent to new entrants. Airlines acknowledged that it would be very difficult for a new entrant to get established.

We need competition in the airline industry; we need the Government to free it up. We in Tasmania certainly require the immediate resumption of normal air services through negotiations, settlement or the provision of at least 1,000 air seats a day each way across Bass Strait. We also need Commonwealth assistance to help the tourist industry recover from this serious and debilitating crisis. Tasmanians are imploring the Prime Minister, the airlines and the pilots to negotiate a resolution to this dispute because the entire Tasmanian economy rests upon it.

Let us remind ourselves that during the financial year 1988-89, the foreign exchange from tourism reached $6.5 billion, and tourism was employing 450,000 people, or 6 per cent of the work force. In its current economic situation Australia cannot afford to put one of its leading industries in jeopardy because of the incompetence of the Prime Minister. The Government should do more to resolve the situation, with communications between all parties involved in dispute. We need to remind Mr Hawke not to talk only to his friends and his mates, that there are other people that are very crucially affected by this.

In the Northern Territory we are losing $400,000 a day, and if this continues it will complicate and compound to $700,000 a day as the crippling dispute continues to ground domestic flights around Australia. In the Northern Territory tourism is the second largest industry, with expenditure of $398m in 1987-88. Forty-nine per cent of visitors travelling into and out of the Northern Territory, to places such as Kakadu, to Uluru- Ayers Rock, to Lichfield Park and Katherine Gorge, with which so many people are familiar, depend on air traffic in and out. We certainly feel the impact in other important tourist destinations, places such as Cairns, Broome and Tasmania. The Northern Territory last financial year had 886,000 tourists. There should be 25,000 tourists a week there at the moment. These are the matters Bob Hawke should be addressing. In the Northern Territory employment in the tourist industry stands at 10,000 people. What is Bob Hawke saying to these people? The remoteness of the Northern Territory means that people working in the tourism industry cannot afford to lose regular air services. The Hawke Labor Government is abandoning conciliation and consultation in favour of confrontation. It was interesting to read the editorial in the Australian on 29 August. It said:

The ACTU has assented to the use of law suits in civil courts to bring striking workers into line, a course of action it has vehemently opposed in the past. It has raised no objection to the Australian military and imported foreign workers being used to confront strikers. It is clear that in a matter of days we have seen an industrial world turned upside down.

Turned upside down by whom? By, of all people, the Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke. The Opposition does not support the extravagance of the pilots' 30 per cent claim or the disruption to travellers in the tourism industry. But-and a big but-what has the Prime Minister done about it? He is conveniently impotent, searching for a reverse vasectomy. The Prime Minister cuddles up to his old mates, Sir Peter Abeles and the airlines, and Bill Kelty the union heavy. Why? Because of the deals over the two-airlines agreement and the hopelessly failed industrial accord. After six years of Labor, the country is struggling with a $108 billion foreign debt. Bob Hawke is losing more face over this issue. He is typically--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Tambling, you should refer to the Prime Minister as the Prime Minister.

—The Prime Minister, Madam Acting Deputy President, is typically gambling with the fate of the nation and playing stakes with the income, the convenience and the security of every Australian and, like all gamblers, he cannot see when he is on a losing streak; he goes in deeper. Let us consider the comments today of the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, Mr Clyde Holding, as reported in the Australian. SPEECH.PARA: `The airlines wrote to the Government . . . asking for compensation of . . . $20m a week, but . . . It is estimated that the tourism industry, Australia's largest export industry, as losing about $100m a month and that losses would rise to $180m a month by December.
The strike had been `as damaging, if not more damaging, than a natural disaster', Mr Holding said.

When we have a gambling Prime Minister it is the Australian nation that suffers the consequences, and the nation cannot go to Gamblers Anonymous. The clear message to resolve the dispute is negotiate, negotiate, negotiate, and this is what the Prime Minister is frustrating. The Hawke Government is not facilitating negotiations. The Hawke Government is covertly assisting only the airlines.

What about the people Bob Hawke overlooks; the tourists and the families stranded, the tour operators, the hundreds of thousands of small businesses now in desperate trouble? Many will go broke if the Prime Minister does not turn his attention to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —How is Uluru going?

—Uluru is going very poorly. Car rental firms in the Northern Territory say that business is down 80 per cent, while the hotels report dramatic falls of 40 to 50 per cent in occupancy rates. The occupancy rate of the Sheraton Darwin has fallen from 80 per cent to 25 per cent while that of the Four Seasons in Darwin has dropped from 85 per cent to 40 per cent, forcing casual staff to be laid off. The Hotel Darwin has retrenched 25 casual staff in the past week and has lost 28 per cent in turnover. Diamond Beach Casino has given me figures showing dramatic decreases in trade. Accommodation has decreased by 40 per cent; bars by 25 per cent; restaurants by 40 per cent and one cancelled visiting interstate group for the high stakes gaming room was due to cash in this week $350,000.

SPEECH.PARA: In Jabiru, a spokesman for Four Seasons Crocodile Hotel described the consequences of the pilots dispute as disaster. Tour operators are also warning that the Northern Territory's multi-million dollar tourism industry could grind to a halt within days. Six major companies, including Australian Kakadu Tours, AAT Kings Tours Pty Ltd and Territory Park Tours, say that business has dropped off 50 per cent since the start of the dispute, forcing 40 staff to be laid off.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why won't the Government let the airlines talk to the pilots?

—Why not? There are long term consequences that will take ages to rectify. What is the message from the Prime Minister for the hundreds of staff being laid off? Maybe he should even heed the words of Mr Snowdon, the member for the Northern Territory, in the House of Representatives the other day. Obviously even Mr Snowdon cannot get the message through to Mr Hawke. Mr Snowdon said that 300 people in Alice Springs alone would have to apply for social security benefits as tourism operators were forced to lay off staff. SPEECH.PARA: We heard today from the Minister, Senator Richardson, the senior tourism Minister in this place, about the issue. His contribution was both irrelevant and apologetic. What did he talk about? The defence planes for places like the Hamilton Island resort on junket deals. Senator Richardson went out on a limb by saying he wished he could find a principle. If he could just find another principle it would be the second one he has ever found. That is, he should resign as the tourism Minister in disgust with the Prime Minister. Senator Schacht was boring; he droned on and merely sought to bring out `half-true' facts. Senator Knowles quite rightly pointed out that the Liberal-National Party coalition does have a policy. The Opposition is not lacking in making a contribution and wanting to get involved. Very obviously Senator Schacht is ignorant of what happens in the Parliament and in the broader community.

Back to the Northern Territory: we need to be reminded that where there is a grounding of domestic flights there will be visitors stranded thousands of miles from home and the local tourism industry is thrown into chaos. If there is an 80 per cent drop in domestic flights, and that is highly likely at the moment, we need to be reminded that expenditure will drop by $250m per month. Overseas operators are warning travellers to stay clear of Australia until the dispute is over and if there is a 30 per cent drop in overseas tours, which is likely to be the drop in September, then the loss will be $100m in foreign earnings. How do we pick that up? How do we turn around that type of major loss? Only the Prime Minister can solve the problem by getting people to the negotiating table. It is the Prime Minister's responsibility to get everybody back and talking.

The time has come for a change after seven years of a Hawke Government which cannot face reality. We cannot afford any longer to go on gambling with Australians. The message comes through very clearly. It is a matter of negotiating, negotiating, negotiating an agreement, and until the Prime Minister faces up and accepts his responsibility in that regard there will not be a solution and it will be the Australian public that will suffer as a consequence.

I note from the speakers list that I am to be followed by Senator Aulich from Tasmania; he gives himself as the Tasmanian senator. Now that he lives in Canberra, obviously he does not need to go home at weekends-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is completely wrong. It is a disgusting allegation. You are a sleazy character.

—We need to be reminded, as I said, that so many groups will have to be re-established in the community following a strike of this nature. So many industries associated with tourism will be affected. There will be a flow-on effect for much of the business community. Advertising agencies, international promotion groups wanting to travel around Australia, and businesses wanting to hold conferences, conventions and seminars, are important to both the whole economy and tourism in Australia. What about places like the Gold Coast, the Barrier Reef or Tasmania, where it is very important that business continues as normal? The casinos in those places will not survive on the patronage of the one person who will have the opportunity to get to them regularly-the Prime Minister. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to discuss the matter of public importance brought forward by the Opposition. There is no doubt that we do agree on one thing: the strike has been particularly damaging to the tourism industry, which is being brought to its knees-as is this nation, to a large extent-by the action of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots. I do not intend to respond to some of the personal attacks that Senator Tambling made on both the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and me. His speech indicates exactly where we differ on how to resolve this issue. His criticism, of course, was about the way in which the Government has handled this strike. The Australian people do not seem to believe that the Government is wrong in the way in which it is handling this strike. I will read to the Senate a report which came to me a few minutes ago of a telephone poll conducted by the reputable organisation, AGB McNair, which polled 1,300 people in the five mainland States over the weekend about the way in which this Government had been conducting itself during the strike, and had been handling issues related to the strike. The document reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government has won strong public backing in every aspect of its handling of the domestic airline pilots row, according to a survey released today. An overwhelming majority of people condemned the action taken by pilots, backed the Government and airlines in refusing the demands, and supported the use of the RAAF and international airlines.

The figures, first released today; were commissioned by the Nine Network Pty Ltd. The poll found that 61 per cent of those interviewed backed the decision by the Government and the airlines to refuse the pilots' demand for a 30 per cent pay increase. Only 27 per cent disagreed. Sixty-eight per cent of those polled disagreed with the pilots' action, while only 10 per cent agreed. The Government's decision to call in the Royal Australian Air Force and international carriers won even stronger support. Eighty-four per cent agreed with calling in the RAAF and 10 per cent disagreed. Eighty per cent agreed with allowing international airlines to carry domestic passengers, and only 12 per cent disagreed. The point made very clear by that poll is that the Australian people are backing the Government to the hilt on its stand on this issue, that the tough stand that has been taken by the Prime Minister and this Government in relation to forcing the Air Pilots Federation back into proper wage negotiations is backed by the Australian public. Therefore, this Government comes into this chamber without any doubts as to where it should be going, but we do have doubts about the approach taken by the Opposition. It is a great shame that, in a moment when this nation needs a Parliament that is solidly behind the proper wage fixing principles and solidly behind doing the right thing in the wage fixing area, we should have to debate this issue raised by the Liberals today.

It is interesting that the question of the accord has been raised on a number of occasions during this debate. The Liberal Party hates the accord. It hates the accord for one reason, and one reason only-because it is a success. It has enabled the Government, through agreement between employers and employees in this country, to reduce real wages to make Australia competitive and trade off better social service benefits such as the tax-free family allowance supplement, to lift employment by more than one million jobs primarily in the private sector and to reduce strikes to 60 per cent of the level which applied when the Liberals were in office. The improvement has been dramatic. It is a commentary that has been made on this Government's handling of industrial relations over the last five or six years by all informed commentators.

Let us look at this dispute. We have an elite group of people bringing this nation and this nation's tourist industry to its knees. Who are they backed by? By the Liberal Party. The Liberal Party is backing an elite group. What is their employment situations? Let us look at them in comparison with the situation overseas. They are not struggling workers. These people are in a position of privilege, and yet being in a position of privilege has not in any way diminished their greed. We are now looking at nearly 30 per cent in terms of their wage application. They are going outside the system to get what they want and using any means that they have at their disposal; not caring whether or not they bring this nation to its knees. Let us look at what they already have, never mind the 30 per cent increase they are seeking in the next few months. They have their seniority system. Where else do they have a system that allows senior officers to pick and choose from the roster as to whether or not they will fly certain routes and in fact whether or not they will fly at all? A senior captain, for example, can pick a stand-by roster which means that he gets paid even if he does not fly. It is not much fun for some of the junior pilots but the senior officers, who are remunerated close to $130,000 a year, are able to pick and choose not to fly and still be paid for it. They can pick, for example, the easier routes-Sydney to Melbourne, say-and be home at night. They can choose where they want to live and the airlines will bring them to their work. They can command salaries of up to $130,000 a year. They work 80 to 85 hours a month-that is, 20 hours a week total duty. Who else in this country has that sort of working arrangement? Thirty-two hours a month is spent at the stick, that is, flying-eight hours a week. They are able to stay, under their award conditions, at five star hotels and they are entitled to and use limousine transport. These are just some of the little extras on top of those conditions. Do not take my word for it. Let us have a look, for example, at a memorandum sent out by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots from Captain B. A. Fitzsimmons to all Ansett Transport Industries Ltd pilots. I will quote from this document which was sent to them:

Firstly, there is nothing wrong with the 1988 ATI agreement. It is an excellent document that contains and maintains some of the best working conditions in the world of aviation and allows pilots to increase their pay without downgrading promotional opportunity.
He said further:

You are the only bid system pilots in the world who have a block guarantee of pay. In all other bid systems if pilots lose flying, that is cancellation or substitution and so on they also lose pay. The pilot then must chose flying for the rest of the month via a make-up book. Many pilots in the United States end up with a quarantine minimum of 65 hours. How long is it since ATI pilots in Australia have had the same problem?' In Europe the pilots work to rosters. This guarantees pay but attracts no penalties for changes to the roster at any time.

We can go on through any number of pages here in which Captain Fitzsimmons explains completely and very clearly exactly what conditions these elite pilots have in this country, enjoyed nowhere else in the world. So what happens? They take on the airline industry. In fact they take on the tourist industry in search of another 30 per cent on top of those wonderful conditions. What happens in this Parliament? When this Parliament needs every person in it to stand up and be counted on this issue, we have the Liberal Party in bed with the pilots-a most immoral situation. When people need a parliament to stand up and be counted, the Liberals are nowhere to be seen.

I mentioned before that 32 hours a month is all that the pilots in this country spend at the stick. In the United States, as a minimum they are expected to fly 50 hours per month, which is nearly a doubling of that which is required under the current situation or employment conditions enjoyed by the pilots in this country. So they have it made.

Let us look at the way the pilots have negotiated. They have gone to the airlines. They have run rolling strikes. They have worked on a nine to five campaign. They have withdrawn from the industrial relations system. They have had their awards cancelled.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise on a point of order. All the way through Senator Aulich's speech he has accused the Opposition of agreeing with the pilots. He knows as well as I do that that is 100 per cent inaccurate. he should be asked not to repeat it.
—There is really no point of order.

—Of course there is no point of order, because the Liberal Party is supporting the pilots. It is as simple as that. By being so wimpy and weak about the way they should be approaching them, the Liberals are supporting them. I do not retract from that at all. So, what happens? The pilots ultimately resign, on AFAP letterhead, which is presented in Melbourne in such a way that one can only come to the conclusion that that letterhead, that resignation, was circulated prior to any individual decision being made by those pilots. In other words, the pilots had already pre-dated their resignations, and that was another part of strangling the Australian economy. It was a carefully calculated attack on the Australian economy and those people who were left stranded, tourists and other people in this country. The pilots planned this more than seven months ago. In a circular sent out by the pilots called `Deadline 89, Issue No. 3' four pages of advice is given to the pilots, indicating to them that a big industrial dispute is on the way. Seven months or so ago this was circulated. It explains how to reduce expenditure. It gives details about the way the pilots should rearrange their personal financial arrangements. It talks about avoiding major expenditure items which are desirable but not essential-I presume that means that they should buy a Holden rather than a Porche. It says, `Be prepared to adjust your lifestyle in the period leading up to and during the NIP', as it calls it-that is, the `no income' period. It even has a nice little cosy phrase to describe the way it strangles this economy: `Be prepared to adjust your lifestyle in the period leading up to and during the NIP', says the circular-`e.g. Eating at home is cheaper than eating out'. In other words, a few of these high flying elite groups must be told that somehow or other one does not eat at restaurants all the time; it is actually cheaper to eat at home. I could go on through a number of items here which clearly indicate that this has been in the planning for a long time.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not the case of a small union picked on by the Government, picked on by the employers, which downed tools and said, `We are not getting justice'. This is the elite group of the Australian work force, backed by the Liberal Party, strangling this economy, leaving people stranded, leaving the tourist industry up the creek.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. I would just draw your attention to the fact that two weeks ago in this place Senator Aulich himself, on behalf of the Government, was refusing to support any mechanisms which would put pressure on people like the pilots.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. This happens every time I speak on industrial relations; every time there are two or three people taking points of order. For what purpose?-to gag me; to ensure that I do not finish my speech. I have never taken a point of order on this issue in the middle of a speech on any honourable senator opposite, yet every time I rise to speak Senator Newman, Senator Walters and the same old hacks from way back want to get up and interrupt my speech. In the two minutes or so that I now have remaining, I will finish on this point. The Opposition--

—I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. Senator Aulich, indeed, took a point of order on Senator Tambling during this very debate. It is a pity that Senator Aulich does not tell the truth.
—There is no point of order.
—I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. I would ask Senator Aulich to withdraw his comment that people on this side of the chamber are hacks.
—Senator Aulich, I do not think it is a very parliamentary phrase. Perhaps you could rephrase it.
—Yes, Madam Acting Deputy President, I retract the phrase. I replace it with `out of touch, ignorant and in favour of what the pilots stand for', which is holding the Australian public to ransom.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a further point of order. That is a most insulting withdrawal and I will not accept it. I ask you to ask Senator Aulich to amend his speech.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I ask you to reconsider your request that Senator Aulich withdraw the term `hack'. —Perhaps it may not be unparliamentary, but I still think that some of the language that has been used here this afternoon has been rather extraordinary. I regret that these terms and phrases have to be used.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I would like to speak on that point of order. I thank you for your patience. As you well understand, I have now been interrupted six times during my speech. I am, therefore, happy to withdraw any of the phrases that upset the Opposition and to finish by quoting Dr Hewson, who said `You would not be getting a claim of that size under our system'--
—Your time has expired!
—Order! I realise that Senator Aulich's time has expired but I think Senator Aulich is entitled to finish his sentence.
—Thank you, Madam Deputy President, for your patience and understanding. I will finish by quoting Dr Hewson, who said `There would not be a claim of that size under our system'.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had debate this afternoon on the appalling effects of the pilots dispute and the airline industry but more particularly its appalling effects on the tourism industry and the industries affiliated with the tourism industry. Let us be quite clear. This dispute is badly affecting the airline industry, but the economic effects of this dispute on the airline industry are as nothing compared with its economic effects on the tourism industry. The effects on the tourism industry will bring this country to its knees in a way which no impact on the airline industry will ever do.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us be quite clear. The Opposition is not supporting the pilots claim for a wage rise of 30 per cent. The Opposition is not supporting the disruption to the affairs of the travelling public. The Opposition is not supporting the effects of that upon the tourism industry. What the Opposition is supporting is the view that those responsible for this situation are principally the Government, and in particular the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of this country. If I have to mention two other gentlemen who might be said to be his collaborators in this matter, they are, respectively, Mr Bill Kelty, the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), and Sir Peter Abeles, the head of the Ansett organisation. Mr Hawke, in support of his friend and little mate, Bill Kelty, has brought to bear the full weight of the Commonwealth, the full weight of the Industrial Relations Commission, and the full weight of the Commonwealth purse, covertly promised to Ansett Airlines, in support of keeping the airlines from negotiating with the pilots. We are familiar in this place with the view being put to us by the Government that we should at all times pay attention to what the Government, with its ACTU background, calls `industrial relations realities'. Let me tell the Government that one of the industrial relations realities confronting this country at present is that there is a very strong association of pilots determined, rightly or wrongly, to get, if not their way, a big part of their way, in this matter. The Government's only response is to say, `On no account are Ansett Airlines and Australian Airlines to negotiate with these fellows'. Does that connote industrial relations reality? Is the whole of the tourism industry in this country to be sacrificed to the overwhelming vanity of this Prime Minister of ours?

TALK.START.PARA: —Narcissus Hawke.

—Narcissus Hawke, as Senator MacGibbon quite rightly calls him. Is this to be the basis of policy in this country-the policy of a vain little man who has injected himself into this industrial relations dispute and is now determined that under no circumstances will this dispute be solved on any terms other than those that he, Mr Kelty and Sir Peter Abeles are laying down.

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment the pilots wish to talk to their employers. In the end we know that that is the only way in which this dispute can be settled; it always is. Yet the Government will not let the airlines negotiate. What is more, the Government is covertly entering into understandings with the airlines that they will be provided with financial support to pick up the losses they are making by refusing to negotiate. Were it not for that understanding being given to Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines-the latter, of course, the government airline, anyway-they would have to go back to the negotiating table, which is where they ought to be. That is where the agreement which will eventually have to be hammered out would be hammered out. Do we have to go through another week, another month, another two months of this?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order them to the table.

—One does not have to order them to the table; one just has to get the Government out of the way and they will be back at the table tomorrow. That is the only problem; Mr Hawke is standing in the way. His vanity and his personal relationship with Mr Bill Kelty are in the way, as is the failed accord, which, after 6 1/2 years of this Government's policies, has delivered to this country $108 billion worth of foreign debt. That is the great contribution which the accord has made to this country, and that is what the Prime Minister is now attempting desperately to prop up in defence of his friend Bill Kelty. Because of that, not only do we have this tremendous disruption to the travelling public of this country, but also-and this is the subject of this debate-the tourism industry of this country is going down in flames. The effect, particularly on the international segment of our tourist industry not just now, not just until whenever it is that this dispute is finally settled, will last for years. Yet the Government appears to be totally unconcerned by this, and that is a sign of the presence of a Prime Minister such as we have today.
