DEBATE.TITLE: SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON COMMUNITY AFFAIRS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report: Income Support for the Retired and the Aged: An Agenda for Reform

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Mr Deputy President, for some reason or other Senator Tate seems to think we only call quorums when someone in particular is not here. There were not enough people in the Senate, hence a quorum was called. The Government has responded to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs report. The Senate gave the terms of reference to the Committee in September 1983 and it was not until December 1988, following two elections, that this Committee finally reported. The Government has now responded to that report.

The Government's response to this report is really a rewrite of the Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I was rather surprised to see that the opening paragraphs had nothing to do with the report but indeed were just telling us how much the Government had done for pensioners in this latest Budget and what good fellows they were as regards the action that the Government proposed to take. The Government put it very clearly that not now, but soon, the pensioners would get $2 a week increase over and above the normal consumer price index increases-$2 a week, not now, as I say, but in April next year. It was telling the pensioners that that was quite a considerable increase for them and what good fellows Government members were.

The Government then went on to say that by 1995, if you please, pensioners will not have to pay tax. What it did not say is that Budget Paper No. 1 points out that in 1988-89 the Government took $7m in tax from superannuation, but it also points out that the Government expects this next financial year-that is, financial year 1989-90-to be taking $885m in tax. There is a fair bit of difference between $7m last year and $885m this year and it does not take a great deal of thought to work out that if the Government is ripping off about $880m extra this year, the pensioners and indeed all superannuants will be down by that particular amount. It is an incredible amount and I think that it must be pointed out to all those on superannuation that the Government in its recent legislation has indeed made big money grabs in that area.

Also, the Government has not pointed out in its response that while it is prepared to give pensioners $2 a week in 1990, it is willing to give members of the House of Representatives a 240 per cent increase in their stamp allowance. What it has done is give $21,525 extra a year-that is more than the average pensioner would ever dream of having-just to spend on stamps. That of course is going to be indexed and now represents $32,090 per annum with the new increase from 1 September when the stamps went up to 41c. It is absolutely hypocritical of the Government to say to pensioners. `We will be giving you an extra $2 a week and by 1995 you won't have to pay tax, but in the meantime we will backdate to last July an additional $21,525 for the members of the House of Representatives'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Walters, your time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly I want to congratulate the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs for the report which, of course, was brought down some months ago, and to note that the Government's response has not been entirely adequate in the points that were made in the course of that report having been tabled. Secondly, though, I must point out that that report came into existence after five years of inquiry by that Senate Committee. I think it behoves this Government to see that its response to that very long and very important report should not appear as one of the papers lodged by the Government in the ordinary list that comes down each day. Rather we should have seen a full inquiry report given to the Senate in the form of a proper response, read out by the Minister in this chamber, so that all could take part in this debate in a proper way. To respond to the points in the report in the space of a mere five minutes does not do justice to the system and does not pay due regard to the proper parliamentary role of senators.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, the important point is surely this: this response is another part of the long, sorry saga of the dealings of the Hawke-Keating Government with the superannuants and pensioners of this country since it came to power in 1983. As well, we remember the promise given during the period before 1983 when the Government, then the Opposition, said, `Of course we would not introduce any assets test. We would not tax superannuation', but of course as soon as it was elected it then set about doing all those things, plus a lot more. But the thing that stood out in the course of the period when we saw the introduction of the superannuation tax in 1983 and the various changes to pensions, including the assets test in 1983, was simply that the Government had no comprehensive policy whatsoever for dealing with retirement incomes.

It was that which in 1983 caused the Senate, forced by this Opposition, together with the Australian Democrats, to set up this very inquiry which is the subject of this report. It was that Committee which sat down over that long period and has brought down what I believe to be a most comprehensive plan, subject to some problems some Opposition senators would have with some details of it. That report does indeed, I believe, bring down the first most comprehensive report for a policy that this country has ever seen. Of course other things have occurred as well. The Government introduced its infamous changes last year on superannuation taxes which, as my colleague Senator Walters, pointed out very eloquently, in a full year, rips, eventually, $1.5 billion out of the taxpayers' superannuation funds.

That means that eventually superannuants will suffer because those taxes will be paid in advance. The Government said in introducing that legislation that no superannuant would lose one cent of his superannuation as a result of that tax. Of course, that is a nonsense. Everybody knows that superannuants will miss out on superannuation benefits as a result of those taxes being brought forward. What was the point of that exercise? It was merely to make Mr Keating's Budget in 1988-89 look particularly good. Of course, that will continue during the forthcoming years. What this Government stands condemned for by virtue of its response to this report is that it continues to overtax people in this country and, more particularly, to tax the savings of those who are trying their utmost to look after themselves in retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I wish to speak briefly to this Government response to the report of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs. My Opposition colleagues made a couple of remarks that I thought were worthy of my repairing to the Senate to address. Senator Walters seemed to be outraged that a large part of the Government's response is actually in this year's Budget Papers. One should give congratulations to a government that not only adopted the recommendations of a committee but incorporated a number of them in its Budget on behalf of the current and future retirees of this country. Those of us who sat for five years on that Committee know full well just how complex and comprehensive the inquiry was. Senator Messner seemed not to tell us exactly how this inquiry got started in the first place. The Australian Democrats wanted a royal commission and the Opposition wanted anything except our assets test, so the two combined devilishly to give a term of reference to the Senate Committee. Senator Messner stuck it out for most of the time but not to the end.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not a bad report at all. The inquiry involved a thorough look at the needs of people under the age pension and superannuation schemes and, importantly, how the two together could best help people during their working life to plan for retirement and then be able to enjoy the benefits of retirement.

If the worst criticism is that many of those recommendations have been taken up by the Government and incorporated in this year's Budget, I would have to say, `What better commendation to an inquiry than that?'. I think, too, that the Government's response in this year's Budget does take account of the very important point made in the inquiry that a superannuation system and an age pension system often working at odds with each other is, at the least, insufficient and, at the worst, positively destructive in helping people to plan for sensible retirement and being able to expect a reasonable income in their retirement.

The Government, since it came into office in 1983, has done a considerable amount to improve the age pension scheme, notwithstanding the comments of my colleagues opposite which are just incorrect. The pension system has been significantly altered. There has been an increase in real terms. The proposals under this Budget will see, over the next few years, a further absolute increase in the pension and, of course, a different tax treatment of allowed earnings, so that, for the majority of pensioners whose income is nothing but the pension, there will be a further increase. I am sure that these are the sorts of things on which the Opposition and the Government are at one, that is, that we hope that people in this country can enjoy at least a regular and guaranteed, if modest, income, so that they can expect not to live as paupers once they retire from the work force.

Some of us on the Committee were very concerned for those people, very often women, who have had either little or no time in the work force, as may be the case for many people approaching retirement now. In only rare cases have they had opportunity to make use of the superannuation system and they do not enjoy the tax benefits of people who have been encouraged to save under the superannuation scheme.

The Government's response in the Budget and in this document should be encouraging to the people who bother to sit on Senate committees, very thoroughly examine the issues and write reports, as this Committee did. It was a very long and protracted examination of retirement income, and I think that the recommendations of the Committee, taken up as they are by government in this report and in the Budget, are excellent recommendations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

SPEECH.PARA: The reality of what the Government did and what the Democrats feigned to be satisfied with was this: they brought in a provision that said that only those funds can take advantage of the dropping of the 15 per cent tax that can satisfy the Commissioner for Insurance and Superannuation that only eligible depositors would receive the benefit of that 15 per cent tax. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to talk briefly on this response of the Government to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs entitled Income Support for the Retired and the Aged: An Agenda for Reform. It is rather sad that the Government has only recently suddenly found the aged. This Government has an appalling record of treatment of the aged, and for evidence of that one has to look only at the cynical way in which it is now treating the aged in looking toward the next election. The Government really needs to look far more sympathetically at the plight of the aged and the way in which their planning for retirement and their existence in retirement has to take shape. Everyone in the community but particularly the aged, who are on very limited incomes in many cases, has to cope with the rate of inflation, increased costs of pharmaceuticals, waiting lists in public hospitals. The aged are now forced to pay increased amounts for stamps, one of their major forms of communication, and telephone costs are huge.

SPEECH.PARA: Many of these areas have not been addressed in this reponse. The most cynical response of the lot was of course contained in the Budget, where the Government saw fit to increase the pension by $2 a week. Of course, it is not going to do that until April next year. One may well ask: When will the election be held-in May next year? It is quite clearly just a carrot for the pensioners, to try to woo their votes. It would be rather nice if the Government looked more sympathetically at some of the other areas which could be of true assistance.

There has been an increasing time lag in the actual payment of pension increases. Admittedly, the Government's response to this report has been that it will reduce that time lag of 12 weeks. Of course, that will not be done completely until September 1990. If the Government were really determined to try to help pensioners, it would be looking at reducing that time lag that it has increased, far sooner than September next year. Also, when the Government looks at the effect of the assets test and many other measures that it has taken, it will see that many more pensioners are in dire financial straits than there were some years ago. DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO ABORIGINAL DEATHS IN CUSTODY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The death of anyone in custody is a tragedy and there have been far too many deaths of Aboriginal persons. This report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody is a very welcome one, but it raises the wider issue of deaths in custody generally. I wish to spend a few moments reiterating some matters which were raised in the Senate by Senator Jenkins some months ago about some recent unsavoury events which have left a bad taste and which represent unfinished business as far as some of us are concerned. I refer to some deaths in custody about which some questions remain as to whether there was due process and a proper duty of care exercised.

I remind honourable senators that the first was the death of Daniel Victor Taylor, who died while in prison and was found at autopsy to have an acute necrotising fungal meningo-encephalitis. That may or may not have been treatable. The point is that it was missed when it should have been detected, and this man died. For those who wish to read the account of the coroner's inquiry, the impression arises that the events which occurred for that prisoner, in that prison system, with that illness, were unsatisfactory. Another unsatisfactory matter about that case was that it was revealed at the coroner's inquiry that this particular prisoner had been receiving methadone-I take it he must have had a heroin addiction-and that at or about the time he became ill his methadone was reduced, not because he no longer needed it but as a control mechanism, as a punishment in fact, for certain behaviour he had exhibited in the prison. As a result of that, it was assumed that the symptoms he then developed, which proved to be his terminal illness, were in fact the symptoms of opiate withdrawal-an unavoidable and a quite tragic occurrence.

The second case I wish to mention to the Senate was the case of Nicholas Searcy. This was raised with me by a member of Senator Jenkins's staff who was, in fact, the mother of this young man. I think Senator Jenkins referred to that case, inter alia, in the speech she gave on the adjournment one night. Jennifer Searcy is properly grieving and properly angry about what happened to her son. This was a real tragedy. This was a Jamie Partlic type of story. This young man was a brilliant student, who was committed to the prison for 17 days for a minor infraction. While in prison he developed an illness and died from it. I believe it was another case of encephalitis. Again, not only was there some delay in making a diagnosis, not only was there a delay in instituting proper treatment, but during the time of treatment there was some behaviour which attracted much criticism. I believe this young man was chained to his hospital bed. This was a death in custody with some very unsavoury elements to it.

The third case was that of Malcolm Hatch, who died of meningitis after he had been transferred from Cessnock Prison to the prison hospital at Prince Henry. He died there on 18 July 1988. The fourth, of course, is the case of Jamie Partlic. We know that he did not die, but he has been severely brain injured during a very brief time in hospital; he was a fine defaulter. What should have been a few days in prison has ended up as a life sentence, because he will never recover.

I know the prison medical service in New South Wales, and I know and like the director of the prison medical service. I know they wish to care for prisoners who come under their care. But the population with which they deal is not representative of the community at large. It is more prone to illness; it is more prone, obviously, to some of these illnesses; and it is quite apparent from these cases-quite apart from the cases of Aboriginals who have died in custody-that people with serious illnesses were not picked up as early as they should have been. There is more illness in prisons, there are more problems. There is a duty of care which falls on the authority which I do not believe is being discharged properly in the States of Australia, and I consider that we have a real problem requiring community attention in the years to come.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last time the Committee was discussing these Bills I undertook to provide to honourable senators several papers in answer to questions they had raised. Senator Coulter had asked for an indication of the attendance of parliamentary representatives on the Council of the Institute over a two-year period to the present. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to have the papers. Senator Coulter may wish to look at the response which has been received. As a matter of courtesy, I wanted to hold the debate open for a second to let him look at the document in case he wished to respond in any way to what the Minister for Justice has put down. I should indicate to Senate Coulter that it is the statement of the attendances by the representatives of this place and, I think, of the other place on the Council of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies. I should mention to my colleague Senator Boswell that there has also been a paper tabled indicating the communities that fall within the two far northern regions.

—The papers tabled by the Minister, although helpful to the Committee, are relevant only in so far as they are relevant to the matter before the Chair at the moment. The Committee is considering the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill to which Senator Peter Baume has moved, on behalf of the Opposition, amendments Nos 2 to 10. The question is that amendments Nos 2 to 10 be agreed to.

—Mr Chairman, it is slightly difficult because the Committee adjourned, with the effluxion of time, on Friday at which stage I had started to explain the reasoning behind the Opposition's promotion of this group of amendments. I had not finished that task. I suppose that it is neither helpful nor fair for me to go back over all that territory and I will not do that. But I indicate to honourable senators and to the Committee that the argument which is contained from page 802 to page 806 of last Friday's Hansard sets out the opening arguments which I used to explain some of the amendments which the Opposition is proposing in this group 2 of amendments. I had got to the point, Mr Chairman, of discussing our proposed amendment to paragraph 7 (h), which gives a function to the Commission to take such reasonable action as it thinks necessary to protect Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural material and information.

SPEECH.PARA: I had indicated at that stage that the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies had itself expressed some concern about this clause. I refer members of the Committee to the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs:
In evidence to the Committee the AIAS-
that is the Institute-
expressed further anxiety about the implications of sub-clauses 7 (g) and (h) of the Bill.
It goes on:

The Institute is concerned that these clauses could interfere with the confidentiality of research, and other material in their custody. Any such possibility would also adversely affect future acquisitions of material.

I cannot overemphasise the concerns we have about that part of the unanimous report of the Senate Select Committee. Many of us have served on the Council of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies, as it presently is. I think it is fair to say that many of the researchers in this country have trusted the Institute as being an appropriate repository for what is quite sensitive information. If they were concerned at all about its security and if they believed that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) could have a role to intervene in the security of what is sensitive cultural material, many of them would simply walk away. They would cease doing the work and they would certainly stop using the Institute as an appropriate repository.

The Minister will recall that we sought and obtained an appropriate amendment when the Institute Bill was considered in committee a few days ago. We are now asking that clause 7 (1) (h) of this Bill be amended appropriately to obviate the danger about which we are concerned. What we propose to do simply is to leave out clause 7 (1) (h). I draw to the attention of my colleagues on the Committee that this clause was raised by the Institute with the Senate Select Committee. It was specifically asked to refer to it in its report. I believe the easiest way to resolve the problem which was raised and which was accepted by the Committee is that we should omit that paragraph. I might say that we have chosen to move these nine or 10 amendments together because to do otherwise is to prolong the debate unduly. If it were the wish of the Committee to agree to one and not agree to another, we could seek leave to put the questions separately when the time came.

Amendment No. (8) seeks to amend clause 7 (1) (j) of the ATSIC Bill by leaving out the words `without derogating from the functions or powers of the Australian Bureau of Statistics' with a view to inserting the words `at the request or with the concurrence of the Australia Bureau of Statistics but not otherwise'. We are concerned to ensure that ATSIC, when it operates, does not try to duplicate the statistical functions of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. As we read clause 7 (1) (j), we believe it could seek to duplicate the functions of the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). We are quite happy for ATSIC to carry out any statistical work at the request or with the concurrence of the ABS but we think it should not otherwise so do.

The next amendment we have proposed in this package is an amendment to paragraph 7 (1) (m). I have to foreshadow that it would be the intention of the Opposition in a few moments to seek the removal of clause 8 of the Bill. That is, as it were, a Henry VIII clause-a phrase used by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and understood by most parliamentarians. It is one of those Bills which say that we will write something now and do the rest by regulation later. Clause 8 (2) as it is proposed says:
The power under subsection (1) shall be exercised by notice published in the Gazette.

We do not yet know what those powers are. That particular clause has been referred to by the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, and I will come back to that point in a moment. If we deleted clause 8, we would then want to look again at clause 7 (m), which at the moment proposes that ATSIC's functions could be increased or varied at any time by the Prime Minister conferring functions on the Commission. The Bill states, `by notices in force under section 8'. If, in fact, we are able to amend section 8, it is inappropriate to keep clause 7 (m).

The last amendment in this group, the last one to which I need to speak at the moment, is amendment No (10). I already indicated a moment ago that it proposes that clause 8, on page 8, should be omitted. In its report on the ATSIC Bill the Scrutiny of Bills Committee informed the Parliament, in relation to clauses 8 and 7 (m)-the two to which I have just referred-as follows:
Clause 8 of the Bill allows the Prime Minister to confer a departmental function on the Commission by means of a notice placed in the Gazette pursuant to subclause 8 (2).
Paragraph 7 (m), in referring to the functions of the Commission, states:
Such other functions as are conferred on the Commission by the Prime Minister by notices in force under section 8.
The Committee-
that is, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee-
requested that the notices be subject to tabling to enable them to be subject to the scrutiny of Parliament.
The Scrutiny of Bills Committee informs us that the Minister responded to that Committee as follows:

Clause 8 of the Bill establishes a system by which administrative responsibilities may be transferred from Commonwealth departments to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. It is therefore equivalent in effect to administrative arrangement orders. Such arrangements are not, of course, subject to parliamentary disallowance. As is the case with administrative arrangement orders, the rights or liabilities of persons cannot be affected by the exercise of the power.
The Scrutiny of Bills Committee then went on to say:

The Committee thanks the Minister for his response but regards it as appropriate that notices be tabled. The Committee does not seek that the notices be subject to disallowance but regards it as appropriate that they be tabled.

Significant functions of departments relating to Aboriginal programs are not proposed for transfer to ATSIC. That is a fact. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in announcing his intention to establish the Commission, said that it would deal with all aspects of Aboriginal affairs. That is simply not true. It will deal with many aspects of Aboriginal affairs but not all aspects. Among the departments with sizeable empires in Aboriginal program administration we find, for example, the Department of Employment, Education and Training, which covers the function of Aboriginal employment and Aboriginal education. The Department of Community Services and Health covers Aboriginal housing under States grants. The Australia Council has responsibility for the Aboriginal Arts Board. The Department of Administrative Services is responsible for the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, and has responsibility for electoral education. There are various programs under the Department for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about local government?

—If Senator Tambling waits a few moments, he will find that I, or my colleague, will have something to say about local government. Among them, those programs which I have just mentioned account for $341m in the 1988-89 Estimates. I may be wrong about the figure, but a very sizeable amount of money is involved. At present, that funding is open to examination by the Parliament, it is open to examination by Estimates committees, and the various Ministers of State are accountable for what is done with that money on behalf of Aboriginal people. But at any future time, if things were to become embarrassing, if things were not working well on any of those programs, the Prime Minister, as the Bill is drafted, could simply transfer the functions by notice published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette to ATSIC. They would then become functions of the statutory body and no Minister would have to answer for what was done thereafter.
—That is not right.
—Well, would not have to answer in Estimates committees and the existence of clause 8--
—Why not? The ATSIC estimates will come to the Parliament.

—I have been on different Estimates committees and we have greater or lesser degrees of difficulties examining the functions of some of the statutory bodies. But the existence of clause 8 illustrates the Government's confusion over the ATSIC concept. When the Prime Minister announced his intention to create ATSIC, it was to be on the basis that the Commission would take responsibility for all aspects of Aboriginal affairs. Yet the Bill presents us actually with an enabling clause-a Henry VIII type clause-which could at some future date transfer functions quite different from those which we know are being transferred now at the outset of ATSIC and which could, by being transferred, change the nature and scope of the Commission's powers and functions.

SPEECH.PARA: So while this clause remains public servants working on Aboriginal programs of departments will never know whether they will become ATSIC officials at short notice because if the function were transferred the officers serving the function would be transferred as well. They then of course would be out of the Public Service and be responsible to the elected commissioners.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—I am happy for the Minister to respond and to knock it over. I will then try to answer any criticism. In the case of officers of Aboriginal descent especially, the prospect, I do not think, is very reassuring. So if the clause-that is clause 8-is not defeated, at the very least it should be amended to require that the Prime Minister consult with the ATSIC board before he acts to assign new functions to the Commission. I would suggest that while the amendments have merit, if the Committee felt it could not accede to the amendments-and particularly, say, the proposed amendment to clause 7 (1) (m)-we should have regard to the report of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and we should consider some extension of what is proposed here. I would suggest that it should be the tabling of any notice which would then be subject to disallowance if the Parliament so wished. After all if it is a fair enough transfer no-one would try to disallow it. Making it the subject of disallowance does not mean the disallowance succeeds. I suggest that as things stand at the moment the functions of ATSIC are drawn altogether too widely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek to speak about a particular aspect of division 2, clause 7, the functions of the Commission, and its potential for conflict with local government itself. Today the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) has chosen to put out a press release saying how pleased she is that the Government has supported the declaration by the International Union of Local Government (IULA) in Perth-the world wide declaration on local self-government-and extolling the virtues of the need for local government to be recognised as an integral part of the federal system. It is in the light of the fact that both the Opposition and the Government agree that local government is an important, integral part of a federal system, whilst not agreeing on support for the declaration, that I seek to speak on clause 7. Clause 7 (1), paragraphs (b), (c), (d), (g), (m) and of course clause 8 about which Senator Peter Baume has already spoken, give various powers to the Commission to monitor; to develop policy; to assist, advise and cooperate; to provide information; and to have such other functions as may be deemed necessary by the Prime Minister pursuant to clause 8.

SPEECH.PARA: These functions include monitoring, developing, advising, cooperating and providing information, and finally cover anything that deals with social, economic or cultural development of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders and is conferred with regard to programs conducted by bodies other than the Commission. There are proposals to meet national, State, Territory or regional needs and priorities at the national, State, Territory or regional levels of government. There is a concern expressed in a submission, for instance, by the Australian Local Government Association in April 1988 to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) that Aboriginal community organisations performing local government functions should not be recognised for the purposes of the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act. But then there is another concern voiced, which is that under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission proposals there could be direct funding to Aboriginal regional groups in furtherance of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) aims of self-determination and self-management which could put them directly at odds with local government itself. A similar position could arise with road funding, where local government may well see the day when the Federal Government is funding roads into ATSIC regional council areas. It is rather curious that, on the day that the Government has put out a release saying how important it considers local government to be, we are debating provisions of the ATSIC Bill which indeed put that important role of local government at risk and in potential conflict with ATSIC.

There has been specific concern expressed on these points by councils particularly in Western Australia where a phrase such as `local government as a service delivery agent' may be usurped by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. They would like to seek assurance from the Commonwealth Minister for Aboriginal Affairs that ATSIC will not be competing with local government for Federal funding that normally accrues to local government. A very specific example is given with regard to the road funding question that I raised. A report points out that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs has indeed identified some 3,083 kilometres of Aboriginal access roads in Western Australia that would require upgrading at a cost of $50m. Over a third of this road length falls within a particular shire of Western Australia. Indeed, one could be concerned that the councils being established are more like Gough Whitlam's regional councils and could end up having a most divisive effect. It can be said, without overexaggerating, that there is the potential to split the nation on issues such as these.

Senator Baume has indicated in moving amendments to this proposed legislation that the Government's attitude is one that requires a response more of sadness than of anger, and I think he has been very reasoned in the amendments that he has moved. He has pointed out the grave concerns that confront the nation. My pointing out specifically the potential conflict between local government and ATSIC is done in the same vein. It is done to ensure that our federal system of government, which comprises Federal, State and local governments, is not in any way usurped by the establishment of a set of councils which are quite outside the frame work of our federal system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The series of amendments put forward pertaining to the group functions of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) goes to some very fundamental points of principle that need to be addressed. Senator Peter Baume and Senator Bishop have alluded to these in quite considerable detail. But it is incumbent on honourable senators to read very carefully clause 7 in conjunction with clause 8 because of the subsequent effects if the ATSIC legislation is fully implemented. Whilst there have been a number of issues raised by Senator Bishop, particularly with regard to clause 7 (d) and the application to local government, I would like to point out to the Senate that the Northern Territory Government has devised a very special and successful form of local government called the community government scheme which operates under the auspices of the local government Act of the Northern Territory and provides for a very peculiar, particular and, as I have said, successful form of local government administration where rating is not the normal base for local government. This has been put into effect.

SPEECH.PARA: I am fearful that, through having a Commonwealth agency and the Northern Territory system, we could pit Aboriginal communities into competing for funds and for the form of administration that they think would best serve their local needs. To a certain extent this goes on under the various forms of incorporation that are currently adopted in various areas. Therefore, I fully support the amendments that have been put forward by Senator Peter Baume.
We need to read clause 7 very carefully because it lists the functions of the Commission. Clause 7 (1) (f) states:
to advise the Minister on:
(i) matters relating to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, including the administration of legislation; and
(ii) the co-ordination of the activities of other Commonwealth bodies that affect Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders;

I prefer the wording put forward by Senator Peter Baume because, if one thinks through the logic of that printed 7 (1) (f) clause, this could also involve participation in Premiers Conferences, in the Commonwealth Grants Commission and in a number of other very important areas that are properly the prerogative of both government and the Parliament, and not--

TALK.START.PARA: —How does the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs get to the Premiers Conference?
—No, he does not get to the Premiers Conference.
—Well, this is to advise the Minister.

—It states that its function is to advise the Minister on those particular areas. I believe it would lead to claims in a number of areas where this advice is necessary, including on the administration of legislation and the coordination of other activities. They are very properly issues that do require a degree of coordination, particularly at a Premiers Conference.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 7 (1) (h) gives the areas of heritage that need to be addressed. This matter has been highlighted by the contribution in the Senate the other day by my colleague Senator Bob Collins from the Northern Territory, who pointed out the inadequate and iniquitous way of funding the Aboriginal Cultural Foundation in the Northern Territory. The Aboriginal Cultural Foundation has a very fine history of representing the traditional Aboriginal owners of northern Australia in those things that are very properly cultural. In the last few years we have seen its budget slashed because its members are out of favour with the powerbrokers who seem to advise the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand)-not those in the Department but those on his personal staff or on the staffs of the Northern and Central Land Councils. As a result of their conflict with the Aboriginal Cultural Foundation-a very fine body of men who in so many areas protect cultural and, to a certain extent, sacred matters-the only way in which they have been able to muzzle the Foundation has been in effect to reduce Commonwealth funding available to the Foundation. This has been most unfortunate and, I believe, thoroughly unnecessary. It is causing huge divisions in the body politic within Aboriginal communities and affecting their development in the Northern Territory. Having given those types of local reservations that I can bring from the Northern Territory, I fully support the amendments put forward by Senator Peter Baume.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have here a large number of suggested amendments to the section in this Bill which deals with the functions of the Commission. It is true that the functions of the Commission will change over time and that at present there are a number of areas of government involvement with the welfare of Aboriginal people which are not covered and at this stage not envisaged to be covered by the Commission, as Senator Peter Baume has pointed out. However, it seems to me that the terms of clause 7 and clause 8 are sufficiently widely drawn here so that over time, if the Aboriginal people so choose, certain functions can be transferred into the ambit of the Commission and those functions can be extended, and I believe it is appropriate that that should happen.
—The issue is whether such transfers might be disallow- able, so the Parliament can at least have that say.

—That deals with the honourable senator's amendments to the functions of the Commission, clause 7(m) and 8 specifically. I will deal with that in a moment. Dealing with the amendments in the order in which they have been introduced by Senator Baume, his amendment 2 is to clause 7, lines 13 and 14. At the moment the clause reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission has the following functions:
. . . to monitor the effectiveness of programs for Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders-
and these are the words which the Opposition seeks to leave out-
including programs conducted by bodies other than the Commission.

If I recall correctly the argument for support of that deletion which Senator Baume brought up the other night, it was that that function was too widely drawn. He would seem to be concerned that the Commission may in some way intrude itself into programs which were conducted by bodies other than the Commission. Senator Baume gave several examples. It seems to me that if one is drawing up a commission which is broadly representative of Aboriginal people from the whole of Australia, it is absolutely appropriate that that Commission should be able to look at programs conducted by other bodies. It may well be that there is a program being conducted by a State government, for instance, which is not in the best interests of Aboriginal people. What body other than ATSIC is the appropriate body to look at that function being conducted by that other body, that other program, and say, `Look, that program is not serving the interests of Aboriginal people' or `That program is inappropriate; or it may even be damaging to the interests of Aboriginal people'. Whether it is being conducted by a State government or a private organisation, it seems to me quite appropriate that the body that is democratically elected by the Aboriginal people throughout Australia is the appropriate body to look at those things.
Moreover, I would object to the amendment that the Opposition is putting because I do not think it really does what the Opposition is seeking from it. With those words deleted, the words would be:
The Commission has the following functions:
. . . to monitor the effectiveness of programs for Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders.

In a sense, that is even more general. It certainly leaves the way open for the Commission to look at all those programs which are conducted by anybody, and it therefore does not achieve the purpose for which the Opposition has sought to delete those words.
I turn to the second amendment, that is, amendment (3), to line 15, clause 7. At present clause 7 (c) reads:
(c) to develop policy proposals to meet national, State, Territory and regional needs and priorities of Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders;

The Opposition is seeking to insert in front of those words, `when requested by the Minister'. Earlier in the debate on the other Bills we heard a great deal from the Opposition as to the distribution of powers by the Minister and the powers of ATSIC and the other bodies which we have been debating-the Aboriginal Development Commission in transition, and the Institute. It seems to me that the Opposition, in moving this amendment, is seeking to do something quite different; in fact, it is diametrically opposed to what it attempted to do in the ADC Amendment Bill. It is a rhetorical question, but why should ATSIC be confined to developing policy proposals, which are not necessarily things which ATSIC would implement or would be able to implement? Surely, it should be in a position to look at various aspects of Aboriginal life and develop broadly drawn policy proposals which address national, State and Territory concerns. It should not be limited to being able to do those things only when requested by the Minister. I see that recommendation by the Opposition as quite severely restricting the ability of ATSIC to develop those policy proposals. This, of course, has implications further on when ATSIC is to make representations to the Minister in relation to Aboriginal policy. ATSIC clearly has to develop its policy proposals in its own mind before it can properly advise the Minister. I think that the insertion of those words is quite unacceptable, having regard to what I see ATSIC as being about.
I will now deal with Opposition amendment (4), that is, clause 7, lines 18 to 20, leave out paragraph (1) (d), and insert a paragraph. Clause 7 (d) at present reads:
(d) to assist, advise and co-operate with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, organisations and individuals at national, State, Territory and regional levels;

Senator Baume seemed to be arguing that that in some way conferred on ATSIC a hegemony over those other organisations; that somehow ATSIC could control and unfairly influence the functioning of the organisations with which it may cooperate or which it may choose to assist or advise.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least it seems to be limited in its ambit.

—It seems to me to be appropriate to insert that and to give it those sorts of powers to assist, advise and cooperate. I do not see any threat of hegemony-and I think that is the word that Senator Baume used-by ATSIC over those other organisations by the inclusion of that clause. Moreover, the words that the Opposition is seeking to include there are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (d) in connection with matters that are functions of the Commission because of other provisions of this Act, but not in any other circumstances, to assist, advise and co-operate with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities . . . and individuals.

It seems to me, as I indicated earlier, that Senator Baume is seeking to restrict ATSIC in its ability to develop policy proposals, and he is then seeking to further limit its ability to assist and advise by way of that earlier limitation. It certainly seems to me that that argument there is unfounded. I do not see the element of danger to which Senator Baume has drawn attention. It seems to me appropriate that this major national representative body, having the appropriate power, as I have indicated earlier, to develop policy proposals should have the ability then to say to various groups dealing with the welfare of Aboriginal people `We support this program' or `We do not support it'; `We will offer assistance with that program' or `No, we will not offer assistance' or `We will cooperate in this or that program for the better management of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander affairs'.
The next amendment, No. (5), is to leave out paragraph (1) (e), which reads:
to establish, where desirable, extra consultative arrangements with the Aboriginal people or the Torres Strait Islander people;

Frankly, it does not worry me very much whether this paragraph is in or out. It does not seem to be a very significant amendment. If clause 7 (1) (d) is in there to assist, advise and cooperate, then of course that embraces the notion that it is possible to establish, where desirable, extra consultative arrangements because clearly one cannot assist, advise and cooperate without those arrangements. I am not sure why the Opposition wants to delete it. I see nothing of great danger in having it in there, but if it were left out the powers which are conferred on the Commission by that clause would be there anyway by reason of 7 (1) (d). I would like to hear from the Minister as to whether he has any other concerns in relation to that one.
In the sixth amendment the Opposition is seeking to leave out paragraph 1 (f), which reads:
to advise the Minister on:
(i) matters relating to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, including the administration of legislation; and
(ii) the co-ordination of the activities of other Commonwealth bodies that affect Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders.

Again the Opposition is seeking here to put up front `when requested by the Minister' to advise the Minister on matters relating to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs. I am surprised, in view of the arguments we heard earlier in relation to the Aboriginal Development Commission Amendment Bill, that the Opposition here is seeking to constrain ATSIC from offering advice to the Minister de novo and saying that it can offer advice to the Minister only when the Minister requests that advice. It seems to me that is a serious limitation on the ability of a body which, after all, is the peak body that will democratically represent the interests of Aboriginal people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except, of course, they could ask the Minister to give them such a direction. He does not have to agree.

—Is it not a peculiar tautology that we must have the wording `when requested by the Minister' and then Senator Baume is saying that what would happen normally would be that the Commission would go to the Minister and say, `Please, Minister, will you ask us XYZ and then we will advise you'? As Senator Baume has rightly pointed out, the Minister could say no. I just see it as absolutely essential for ATSIC that it have the ability to go to the Minister and say, `Look, Minister, we think that in this area XYZ should be done'. Whether or not the Minister accepts that advice is left with the Minister, but ATSIC has the ability to go and give that advice, unwelcome as it may be. I deal now with the seventh amendment of the Opposition, which is to leave out paragraph 1 (h). That paragraph states:

SPEECH.PARA: To take such reasonable action as it thinks necessary to protect Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural material and information, being material or information that is considered sacred or otherwise . . .
I listened carefully to what Senator Peter Baume said on this and I have great difficulty in following the argument that he raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I would be happy to yield to Senator Coulter, if he wants to complete his remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Boswell. I will not take a further 15 minutes to deal with the remaining items. I was dealing before the dinner break with Opposition amendment (7), which seeks to omit paragraph 1 (h) of clause 7. That is the clause which Senator Peter Baume was saying in some way cuts across the role of the Institute in its protection of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural material and artefacts, et cetera-things that are sacred. As I read that paragraph, it allows the Commission to act as an adjunct to the work of the Institute and it in no way inhibits the Institute, or interferes or needs to interfere with its work. It seems to me that there may be instances in which broader action which could be taken by the Commission may well be necessary as a precursor or as an adjunct to some action which the Institute found necessary in the protection of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural material or information, et cetera. Therefore, I do not accept the Opposition's argument with respect to the deletion of that paragraph.
—I will offer more argument in a moment because I think that is fair enough.

—I thank Senator Baume. The next Opposition amendment, amendment (8), leaves out certain words and inserts alternative words. The words to be left out are, `without derogating from the functions or powers of the Australian Bureau of Statistics' and the insertion is `at the request or with the concurrence of the Australian Bureau of Statistics but not otherwise'. It seems to me that that amendment does not significantly change the meaning of that clause. For that reason, while I will listen with interest to what the Minister has to say, it would not matter too much which form of words was included.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume dealt with the remaining two amendments at some length, that is, the ability of the Prime Minister, by notice under clause 8, to confer other functions on the Commission, and clause 8 itself, which the Opposition is seeking totally to delete. Clause 8 reads:
The Prime Minister may, for the purpose of furthering the social, economic or cultural development of Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders, confer a departmental function on the Commission.
(2) That the power under subsection (1) shall be exercised by notice published in the Gazette.

Senator Baume seemed to be arguing that in some way this got around the processes of parliamentary scrutiny. That seemed to be the main thrust of his argument here. I cannot quite see that, because there are other provisions within this Bill which set out the way in which budgets and plans and various other things shall be developed by regional councils and then by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission itself, and the way in which the Minister will have an overview of those budgets; and moreover, that if the Minister disagrees with any part of those draft budgets, he must make known to both Houses of Parliament the differences between what ATSIC has requested and what he is imposing upon ATSIC, and the reasons for those changes. With that degree of scrutiny, I have difficulty in seeing that there is any failure on the part of the Parliament to properly administer its responsibility in scrutinising the functions which may be transferred from other departments to ATSIC by way of the subclause of clause 7 and the whole of clause 8. For that reason I am not convinced by Senator Baume's argument.

The appropriateness of the actual transfer-leaving aside for the moment the question of scrutiny by the Parliament-is precisely the issue we have been dealing with throughout a number of these clauses. I come back to the point I made right at the beginning of my remarks, and that is that as ATSIC develops I would certainly see it as an organisation capable of taking on more and wider functions with respect to both Aboriginal welfare and Aboriginal economic and other development. For that reason it is appropriate to have a mechanism written into this legislation by which that transfer of powers can occur. I think the width of the potential here is defensible on the grounds of that implicit hope that ATSIC will develop along those lines and will become a properly representative body able to function in the interests of Aboriginal people. It is a hope I have expressed several times.In summing up this series of proposed amendments, it seems to me that, while there are two in there which I think are not particularly significant either way-and I would be prepared to be convinced either way on those-the remainder of them, are necessary for the purposes for which the Government is creating this body through this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had better indicate the Government's general approach to this package of amendments, which are known as group 2 in the Opposition's sequence of amendments. Generally speaking, the effect of carrying the various amendments, certainly cumulatively, would be to narrow the functions of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) and, quite paradoxically, given some of the statements made by the Opposition, to put in a form of ministerial control or veto over the exercise of some of the functions which, in any case, are to do mainly with the giving of advice and so on, and do not really amount to the exercise of real effective power in any case. So we find them rather strange, and I do not believe they sit all that well with some of the expressions of the Opposition in relation to the debates we have had up to this point.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Coulter has done a remarkable job going through the various proposals within group 2, but I shall do the same for the sake of completeness. As to the first amendment to clause 7, this is simply a matter of enabling the Commission to monitor the effectiveness of programs for Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders in relation to certain matters. It seems to me that to keep an eye on the effectiveness of those sorts of programs would really be a necessary basis for that sort of advisory role. Even self-advice needs to be generated, if you like, by the Commission, and to have an understanding of the effectiveness of programs for Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders, by whomsoever they are conducted or made available, would be a very sensible element in the awareness necessary to the Commission if it is to devise the correct strategies available to it within its own functions and powers and to offer such assistance or advice as may be helpful to other bodies conducting programs on behalf of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. So it seems to me that that really is a very sensible function and I cannot quite see the peril that is thought to be there. I agree with Senator Coulter that to leave out the words `including programs conducted by bodies other than the Commission' would probably have no effect on the real scope of that clause. Nevertheless, the Government obviously would stand by 7 (1) (b) as it is presently drafted.

As to the third amendment put forward by the Opposition, here once again the Opposition appears to be putting a form of ministerial constraint on the operations of the Commission. After all, this is only a function to develop policy proposals, and to require that before that could be undertaken a request has to come from the Minister seems to put an unnecessary constraint and shackle on the Commission. I do not see why it should not have the confidence of this Parliament that it could at least develop policy proposals without having to be given the go-ahead by the Minister. It seems to me to be a perfectly sensible and proper arrangement that it should generate for itself the areas of concern and come up with proposals to deal with those matters.

As to amendment No. (4), this seems once again to be unnecessarily constraining the scope of the matters on which the Commission can assist, advise and cooperate with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, organisations and individuals at national, State, Territory and regional levels. There seems to be a sense of something untoward happening in the operations of the Commission that would lead it to go on frolics of its own around the Australian community if the sort of constraints that are suggested by Senator Peter Baume were not put in paragraph 7 (1) (d), but I believe that really it is unnecessary. I think we can rely on the commonsense and the sense of purpose, the overall composition of the Commission as it would be, to carry out this function in a way which allowed it at times-and I cannot necessarily foresee them-not merely to assist, advise or cooperate in relation to those matters where it already has another function conferred on it but to do other things. There may be matters outside its own list of functions where indeed its assistance would be extremely useful, its advice would be welcomed and its cooperation would possibly be sought by other Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander, communities, organisations and individuals at the various levels.

By the way, when we were talking about the various levels-national, State, Territory and regional-there seemed to be a bit of a suggestion from Senator Bishop in particular that this could lead to the undermining of State and local government provisions of services and responsibility for the provisions of services. I can point to Objects, clause 3 (d), and emphasise once again that the objects of the Act, amongst other things, are:

(d) to ensure coordination in the formulation and implementation of policies affecting Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders by the Commonwealth, State, Territory and local governments, without detracting from the responsibilities of State, Territory and local governments to provide services to their Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander residents.

TALK.START.PARA: —What does `co- ordination' mean? That is one of the things that worry me. The word `coordination' often means control to some extent.

—Then we have to look at the actual functions and powers that are bestowed. When one looks at the functions that are bestowed, one sees it simply in terms of assistance, advice and cooperation. I do not see how one can get any sense of control or domination out of those words. I do not believe that they are there and I believe it is an unjustified concern that explains the amendment put forward by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. (5) of the Opposition is designed to leave out paragraph 1 (e). To be quite frank, I do not care whether that stays in or goes out. I do not quite see that paragraph 1 (e) is essential to this list of functions. Maybe it is there out of an abundance of caution but I would have thought that if the Committee decided that paragraph 1 (e) were not to stay in the list then the consultative arrangements that would necessarily underpin the functions in at least paragraph 7 (1) (d) would be probably quite adequate to the necessary functions of the Commission. I would not go to the wall on that if Senator Coulter decided to support the Opposition. We would not protest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which one was that?

—It was paragraph 7 (1) (e). As to amendment No. (6), once again the advice-according to the Opposition-could be provided only when requested by the Minister. It seems that to advise the Minister refers only to advice at his request. Once again, it does not do full justice to the composition, to the competence, to the self-motivation-not exactly the conferring of functions, because we are going to confer the functions-of the Commission. I think decisions on advising the Minister can be safely, properly and fairly left with the Commission. I do not see that the advice should be triggered at all times by requests by the Minister and I believe that in a sense the almost inherent veto in the sorts of advice which the Minister might ask for would diminish the usefulness of the Commission if that particular preambular requirement were made a part of paragraph 7 (1) (f).

SPEECH.PARA: As to amendment No. (7), I have had a quick look during the dinner hour at recommendation 22 of the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. The recommendation was that the Minister consult the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies (AIAS) on this question and examine either the transfer of responsibility contained in paragraph 7 (1) (h) to AIAS or the amendment of paragraph 7 (1) (h) to require that the Commission be empowered to exercise that power only after consultation with AIAS. I am informed that indeed the Minister did consult with AIAS, that those consultations have occurred and that it did not see it as appropriate that this be its role. On that basis and on that advice I so inform the Senate. I believe that this particular clause ought to be allowed to stand on that basis, that the Institute, the organisation the integrity of whose collection was thought to be at some risk perhaps by Senator Peter Baume in moving his amendment, apparently does not see it that way.

As to amendment No. (8), on the ability of the Commission to collect statistical information, once again I am not particularly concerned one way or the other how this particular clause goes. If Senator Coulter decides to support the Opposition we could live with that.

As to amendments Nos (9) and (10), I found the argument put forward by Senator Peter Baume rather surprising because he suggested that if we moved a function from a department-let us say the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET)-to ATSIC, somehow this Parliament would lose control over the Estimates process. Of course, all the ATSIC estimates will come before this Parliament. Proposed section 55 (1) makes it clear:
There is payable to the Commission such money as appropriated from time to time by the Parliament for the Commission.

We are dealing with parliamentary appropriations in respect of the operations of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and I am quite sure, much to my regret, that I will be sitting through several days of Estimates committees, as I have for the Aboriginal Development Commission and the Department, defending the estimates of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission-or at least if not defending them, allowing, should I say, the appropriate witnesses from ATSIC to explain their estimates to the Committee. That will go on for days and days. I am sure that that will be the case.

Senator Baume seemed to suggest that if we did have, say, a function transferred from DEET to this new Commission, somehow those public servants concerned would lose their Public Service status. That is what I heard Senator Baume say, and once again I do not think that is correct. Personnel in ATSIC will of course be public servants under the scheme of this particular Act. So I believe that the two matters which the honourable senator proposes in regard to these amendments Nos (9) and (10) on examination do not have the impact on parliamentary surveillance of the functions that might be brought into the scope of ATSIC's concerns, and for that reason the Government does not see any need to accept amendments Nos (9) and (10).

As I have I think heard Senator Baume say of our position, as far as the movement, for example, of the function from DEET is concerned I asked my advisers what they could give as an example. They said, `If you take the training for Aboriginal programs which are now in DEET, it may well be that at some future stage you might transfer that particular function across to ATSIC'. They were not indicating that that was on some hidden agenda-I would not want people to think that-but they gave that as an example where you could have it transferred, as does the Prime Minister by administrative arrangements transfer matters from one department to another for reasons of efficiency or such like. That would be the case under proposed section 8.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Tate, your time has expired. You may seek leave to continue.
—I do not think I need to, Mr Chairman. I think I have dealt with all the amendments and I thank the Committee. I have indicated two of the amendments which I might be able to accept.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like the Minister to clarify some additional comments that he has made with regard to the Opposition's amendment No. (4) relating to paragraph 7 (1) (d) where we were talking about the conflicts that could arise at the various State, Territory and local government levels. The Minister did not feel that the Opposition's amendment was needed because of the concerns that we have expressed. I would like to draw to the Minister's attention, under `Powers of the Commission', to paragraph 10 (2) (a), which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The powers of the Commission . . . include, but are not limited to, the following powers:
(a) to negotiate-
I stress the words `to negotiate'-
and co-operate with other Commonwealth bodies and with State, Territory and local government bodies;

There appears to be a conflict inherent in the argument that the Minister has just presented, in which he invites defeat of our amendment No. (4). I therefore ask the Minister: Will he agree to our group 3 amendments, where we seek to leave out the words `negotiate and'? I think this would be most important in order to retain the integrity of what the Minister is saying.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be agreeing to not permit the power in the Commission to negotiate with other Commonwealth bodies and State, Territory and local government bodies. Negotiation requires two parties. There is no sense of dominance, control or exercise of some sort of untoward, paramount force. Negotiation simply means that one sits around a table and talks through a matter in order to arrive at a conclusion.
—What if you do not arrive at a conclusion?
—That is too bad.
—Too bad for whom? The State government or local government?

—Probably for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people. The fact is that to negotiate simply means that one has a series of discussions which one hopes will lead to a sensible conclusion, in the same way in which I negotiate with State Ministers in relation, perhaps, to the provision of legal aid services for the Australian community. If the State government walks away from the negotiation, the matter collapses. It is not an exercise in control. That is not what negotiation means.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned about the Minister's statement. When we debated the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill we debated the fact that the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA) and Aboriginal Hostels Ltd would come under one banner, one mega-commission, which would be called ATSIC. Due to the good graces of Senator Coulter and the Opposition, we removed the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies from ATSIC. On page 7, under `Division 2-Functions of Commission', I believe the Minister is expanding way beyond what he enunciated when he said that ADC, DAA and Aboriginal Hostels would come under ATSIC. He is now widening the powers of the ATSIC Bill. I have some quite large concerns on a number of issues. For instance, I do not see why a State government which puts up its own money-I think in the case of my State, about $38m that it collects from State taxes-should be required to advise or assist ATSIC. This is purely a State matter and if a particular State government wants to develop--
—The money is a State matter and ATSIC is a Commonwealth matter.

—Yes. If the elected members that constitute the government want to participate in some particular Aboriginal venture-whether it be an emu farm or a store, or whether they want to set up cattle properties or provide stock for cattle properties-that is the State government's decision, funded by State government taxes and made by a responsible, elected government. What the Minister is saying here, as I read it, is that ATSIC, which is a Commonwealth commission, will have to advise, cooperate, work, coordinate, negotiate, and anything else one likes to name, with the State bodies. I see that as a complete invasion of State rights. I know that States rights are not near and dear to Senator Coulter's heart, but we do have State governments. That is a fact of life under the Constitution and those State governments provide, particularly in Queensland and the Northern Territory, and probably in a lot of other States, significant funding for Aboriginal communities. They are very effective; in fact, in lots of ways they are closer to the Aboriginal people than we are here in Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: The other area I want to debate is paragraph (d):
to assist, advise and co-operate with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, organisations and individuals at national, State, Territory and regional levels;

In Queensland these local communities have local government status. They are elected every three years under the Local Government Act; in fact, I believe they probably have a few more powers than an ordinary local government council. For instance, I believe they do have some control over Aboriginal police and a few other areas. If ATSIC is going to assist and advise and cooperate with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander regional communities, I think that is a complete invasion of the local government organisation that has been set up-and is working brilliantly in Queensland, I might add. Local governments get their funding from the State government and from the Commonwealth Government and then they make their own decisions as to what they are going to do with that funding. That is self-determination and self-management at the grass roots level.

To have ATSIC coming in to advise, to assist and, I suppose we could say, to negotiate and cooperate I do not think is appropriate. I would hope that we could leave those local communities that have their own local governments to make their own decisions on local government issues. We fought and lost the battle on ATSIC but now we are finding that not only is ATSIC encroaching on the Aboriginal Development Commission, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and Aboriginal Hostels Ltd but the Government is also trying to increase the power of ATSIC to take over local government communities. That is not going to be in the best interests of local government.
Paragraph (h) states:

to take such reasonable action as it thinks necessary to protect Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural material and information, being material or information that is considered sacred or otherwise significant by Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders;

That seems a clear intrusion into the area of the Aboriginal Institute. The Government has agreed, I think unwillingly but as a result of Senator Coulter's assistance and the Opposition's insistence, that the Institute be removed from the ATSIC Bill. Again, the Government is trying to provide the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission with a vehicle to intrude into the area of the Aboriginal Institute. Senator Tate tells us, and I believe him, that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) has talked to the Institute and it sees no objections to this. Again, I do not doubt what the Minister has told Senator Tate but I wonder whether the directors of the Institute realise what this clause will do. It will give the 20 commissioners of ATSIC the right to stampede right into the affairs of the Aboriginal Institute and the material that is there, which needs to be treated with the utmost secrecy. I am sure that it is not in the best interests of the Institute, given all the material that is held in that Institute. I again ask Senator Coulter to reconsider his stand on paragraph (h). I think Senator Coulter is well aware of the needs of the Institute, what material is held there and how that material should be treated. I want to put those remarks on the record.

I support the rest of Senator Baume's amendments. They are reasonable amendments. They are amendments that really define what we were initially told ATSIC would do-amalgamate the ADC, DAA and Aboriginal Hostels Ltd, be responsible for the workings of those previous commissions and departments and bring them under one banner. The clause giving the functions of the Commission exceeds what we debated at the second reading stage and what was mentioned in the Minister's speech. Therefore, I do not see that it accords with what has been laid down by the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that there is a fundamental difference in our interpretations of the words right at the beginning of these several clauses. I draw the Minister's attention to the words at the beginning of clause 7:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission has the following functions:

Opposition senators seem to be saying that the Commission shall exercise every one of those functions mentioned in the clause. In other words, if there is one local government somewhere in Australia that contains one Aboriginal person, the Commission shall exercise the `assist, advise, co-operate' et cetera, functions. That is not the way I read it. The opening words, `The Commission has the following functions', seem to me to have been deliberately chosen. I interpret their meaning-I would like the Minister's interpretation on this-that from time to time any one of those functions may be exercised with respect to any one of those matters but that there is no compunction on the part of the Commission to exercise any function continually with respect to all bodies in which that function can be exercised.

Similarly, Senator Tambling drew our attention to clause 10, `Powers of Commission'. It states that the Commission has power to do all those things. It does not state that the Commission shall exercise that power with respect to all those things. Again, it seems to me that those powers are provided if and when the Commission needs to use them for the fulfilment of its various functions. They do not in any sense obligate the Commission to impose its will on any of those bodies. After all, to `assist, advise, cooperate', and in clause 10 `negotiate', as the Minister has already pointed out, requires two parties to participate. So I would like the Minister's interpretation of, I suppose, the word `has' rather than `shall exercise', which would be the alternative, and his comments as to whether I am interpreting those powers and those functions in a liberal way, which is what is really meant, or whether they really mean what I think the Opposition is arguing and which is clearly raising a great deal of concern on its part.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee can look at various words, and I am happy to talk about those, but the overall purport and intention of clauses 7, 8, 9 and 10 need to be looked at as a whole. If one says that the Commission `has the following functions', all one means is that certain capacities are vested in it, are available to it. These are the sorts of things that it may undertake. Then again, of course, obviously, when one says that the Commission `has power to do all things', one merely asserts that the Parliament intends that it actually have the mechanisms available to it, the actual ability, to undertake those functions which are outlined in clause 7.

SPEECH.PARA: I think what lies behind the Opposition's amendments in this area of our debate is some fear that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission can usurp or override or have some sort of paramount functions which displace the legitimately constituted State or local government organisations or voluntary bodies or associations constituted perhaps under State law or simply community groups that come together in a voluntary way. That is not the case at all. There is no intention in the words, certainly no intention on the part of the Government, but certainly not in the words, to have that sort of overriding displacing power which Senator Boswell, in particular, seems to fear.

I have already indicated that it is quite clear from the objects clause that the Bill is drafted in the intention that State and local government bodies retain their responsibilities and remain answerable to their electorates for the discharge of their proper responsibilities towards their citizens, including the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who fall within their boundaries. Given the fact that we have a federal system, quite clearly when we have a national body such as ATSIC established, it will be important that it work in harmony with-by way of assisting, advising and cooperating with-all those various bodies at the various levels peculiar to the federal system.
