I would just reiterate that the power given in clause 10 (2) (a) is simply to negotiate and cooperate with other Commonwealth bodies and State, Territory and local government bodies. It is in no way an overriding power; it is one which depends on the ability to sit down and discuss with a view to securing the ends and objects which are set out in the functions of the Commission. The functions are, for example:
to assist, advise and co-operate with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, organisations and individuals at national, State, Territory and regional levels.

To carry out that function, it may require the power to negotiate and cooperate with governments at the State and local government level. As I say, the powers clause, clause 10, indicates the real effective capacity, the way in which the functions may be truly exercised for the ends which are set out there.

The Government is not further persuaded by anything that it has heard and we will therefore vote against all the amendments except for the two which I have indicated we can live with if Senator Coulter so indicates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not need to do this, but I remind the Committee of standing order 130, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The President may order a complicated Question to be divided.

We have chosen to group these amendments for the convenience of the Committee, because otherwise we would have been here for weeks and weeks. From what I heard the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) say and from what I heard Senator Coulter say, I foreshadow that I will ask that you, Mr Temporary Chairman, divide the question to separate amendments Nos. (5) and (8). Amendment No. (5) refers to subclause 7 (e) and amendment No. (8) refers to subclause 7 (j). They are the two to which I understand there is no objection.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, not a sufficiently strong objection.

—I am grateful for that. That is a bit later. I do not wish to rehearse the whole argument, but I wish to respond to a few points. After all, we have never asserted-and I think Senator Coulter gave the reason for it-that it was obligatory that all the functions be exercised. I have to speak to a former dean of a law faculty here. I do not really understand the law of mandamus but, if there is a power, is it not a fact that someone with standing can seek an order that the power be exercised?
—Only if it is mandatory, if it is absolutely required to be exercised.

—I accept that explanation. I do, however, want to refer to a few of the amendments for which some response is necessary. The first amendment in this group-that is, amendment No. (2)-has been criticised by Senator Coulter, and Senator Tate has indicated that the Government will not agree. I have to say to the Committee that I have had the experience as a Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, when the same functions were departmental functions, of trying to deal with some of the States of Australia. It goes back a few years, but the three worst States with which I had to deal on these matters, quite apart from whatever provision they made at State level-and I would have to agree with Senator Boswell that Queensland actually provided well-in terms of negotiation, monitoring, assessment, and discussion were the States of Queensland, New South Wales and Western Australia. When I was Minister one was under a National Party government, one was under a Labor Party government, and one was under a Liberal Party government. They were terrible. They would not make officers available to talk. They would not sit round the table. They were very very proud of their sovereignty. They resented any efforts by the Commonwealth to do the kinds of things which are proposed in this functions clause.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all very well our laying these matters down, but I think my colleague Senator Boswell made the point that it is another thing bringing them to fruition. We actually believe that some of these amendments may smooth the way.

I say again, Mr Temporary Chairman, that the second reading debate is over; we are no longer arguing the principles. We have argued and lost that battle. We are concerned that we are all going to end up being very sorry at outcomes which are not going to be desirable. We think there is going to be a backlash if this Bill proceeds without some amendments being put into the clauses. We think the backlash may harm the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) as it tries to function. We think the backlash may affect the credibility of what ATSIC is and what it is trying to do. And it may actually harm the acceptance of the Corporation. That may not be a view that is shared by other members of the Committee-I accept that-but that is one of our concerns. Some of the amendments actually are well motivated by a desire to try to make it more acceptable and more likely to succeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —But 7 (1) (b) does not do what you want.

—Well, that is a point of view. I think 7 (1) (b) was just my first point. I just want to make one other point about paragraph 7 (1) (b). As it is written, it would enable ATSIC to monitor the programs conducted by the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies, because it would enable ATSIC to monitor the effectiveness of programs including programs conducted by bodies other than the Commission, of which the new Institute will be one such body. I just ask honourable senators to keep that in mind because I am going to mention in a moment my concerns about the heritage question again. There is no doubt that ATSIC could say, `We wish to monitor some of the programs as they may affect Aboriginal people and we depend upon clause 7 (1) (b) as the functional head of power because these are programs conducted by bodies other than the Commission'. That will be possible.
—They could do that with your amendment.

—I put it to Senator Coulter that I understand that the courts these days can look at the debates as well as at the Bill and if this amendment were agreed to the courts would be aware of the fact that these words were taken out. That would assist the courts in the weight that they may wish to put on any case that was put before them.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me move straight to clause 7 (1) (h) although it is out of sequence. I think I presented an incomplete case because-I take honourable senators back now to the arguments that we would have put when we were discussing the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies-honourable senators will recall that the Minister very graciously indicated that all our amendments were acceptable and so we did not, in fact, argue the amendments one by one. But one of the amendments to which the Committee agreed when we came to look at the Institute was an amendment which had to do with the way in which we deal with secret and sacred information, with culturally sensitive information. That amendment-I want to read it because it is a different provision from the one which is being written into this ATSIC Bill and this is the point I want to make-was:

Where information or other matter has been deposited with the Institute under conditions of restricted access, the Institute or the Council shall not disclose that information or other matter except in accordance with those conditions.
Those conditions would not apply to ATSIC. Part 2 of what was inserted reads:
The Institute or the Council shall not disclose-
shall not disclose-

information or other matter held by it (including information or other matters covered by subsection (1)) if that disclosure would be inconsistent with the views or sensitivities of relevant Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders.

That amendment was derived by us from this similar provision which existed in the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) Act. So now I say to the Committee: there is a provision in the ADC Act which we have now transferred to the Institute of Aboriginal Studies Bill but we find in the ATSIC Bill, as it is written, an entirely different formulation of words. We believe at the very least that the protection afforded to culturally sensitive information should be no less. It may be that somewhere those same words have to go in to make sure that ATSIC, like the Institute and like the ADC, shall not disclose certain material.
Senator Tambling interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, for whatever reason. I would not like to see funding tied to the release of any information, but I would say to honourable senators that clause 7 (1) (h) provides much less protection. It puts the protection entirely within the judgment of the commissioners of ATSIC because clause 7 (1) (h) as proposed states:

SPEECH.PARA: to take such reasonable action as it thinks necessary . . .

Whereas we have all agreed in relation to the other Bill in the package that under certain conditions `they shall not disclose'. There is a big difference. If honourable senators want to say to me, `Let us put those same words in'--

TALK.START.PARA: —Put those words in in addition rather than leave those out and I would have no objection.

—I think that is a fallback position but something that I would seek to do. I would like to take some advice from the Clerks as to the place where we might want to put it in. I think we should have no less protection in this Bill; that is all. The formulation which we had for the ADC and for the Institute should at least be reflected here. The only other matter to which I wished to return, out of sequence, was proposed section--
—Would any of your advisers have those words?

—I ask one of the attendants to take them across to the Minister. We have already agreed to them and I am happy to send them across. This is written, of course, as part of the Institute Bill, not as part of the other Bill. I return, out of sequence, to amendment (3), which is an amendment to paragraph 7 (1) (c), and say that the arguments which have been advanced are these: `What are we worried about?' and, `What are we thinking of?'. I remind honourable senators again that some of the programs in other Government departments include, for example-and I mention this again-the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, which is administered by the Department of Administrative Services.
—And some functions by the Attorney-General's Department.

—There are functions of the Department of Employment Education and Training, the Department of Community Services and Health, the Australia Council, I think the Attorney-General's Department, the Department of Administrative Services and the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Paragraph 7 (1) (c) says that it is a function of the Commission to develop policy proposals to meet all of these needs. Let us refer, for example, to the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. This subclause is really an invitation to ATSIC to say to another Commonwealth department of state, operating under the constitutional authority given to that Minister of state, that it wants the programs done in this way or that way. Our concern relates to our view of how the Constitution is drawn-we see it as a question of constitutional propriety-and what is meant by ministerial control of portfolio. I am thinking here of the Minister for Administrative Services, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, or whoever it might be. That is what was concerning us when we drew up this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the last two amendments, I foreshadow to the Committee, because I understand what Senator Coulter and Senator Tate have said, that we think that if our amendments are unsuccessful it is still necessary to try to amend the functions as written here. If that were the case, I would then move another amendment seeking to ensure that any instruments which were made to transfer functions under proposed clause 8 (2) should be disallowable instruments for the purposes of section 46 (a) of the Acts Interpretation Act. I foreshadow that to indicate to my colleagues the way in which we are intending to move. I commend the amendments. I say to you again, Mr Temporary Chairman, that in accordance with standing order 130 I will ask that the two I have mentioned be separated for the purpose of voting. I indicate to the Committee that we foreshadow another amendment, should that be necessary, after these amendments have been voted on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I enjoy listening to Senator Peter Baume. He has a very nice, logical mind and I like listening to his arguments. However, in relation to clause 7 (1) (b), I would reflect on a term which he uses quite often, that is, the Latin term, reductio ad absurdum. Using the reductio ad absurdum argument, the argument Senator Baume used was that a court later on could look at the words which were deleted and observe that, having deleted them, there must have been some intention in our deleting them and therefore would not look behind those words. Suppose we were minded to delete 7 (1) (b) altogether in committee. We would have the quite absurd situation in which the Commission could not even monitor the effectiveness of its own programs, which of course would be ridiculous.
—So we have not moved that way.

—No, but I would suggest to Senator Baume that his reasoning is simply not right on that. The only sensible interpretation one could give to the words `The Commission has the following functions . . . (b) to monitor the effectiveness of programs for Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders' would be that it could indeed monitor programs in addition to those programs which it conducted itself-in other words, programs conducted by bodies other than the Commission. That is why I said in my initial remarks in speaking to this amendment that I do not think the deletion of those words achieves what the Opposition intends them to achieve. On the other hand, the inclusion of the words does make clear that the Commission can monitor-and `monitor' is the term that is used-the effectiveness of programs conducted by other bodies, and I think that is appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning quickly to the 7 (1) (h) proposed alternative amendment, which I certainly would support, it seems to me absolutely appropriate to keep 7 (1) (h) in there, as I indicated earlier, because I see it as an adjunct to the function of the Institute. Contrary to the example Senator Baume has given in which he talked about sacred material which may be of a sensitive nature and information which should not be generally divulged or talked about, I would see this clause coming into operation in situations such as the one which has developed in relation to Aboriginal material kept in museums. Aboriginal people have said that much of this material was scavenged in the early days by anthropologists against the wishes or without even considering the wishes of Aboriginal people. There is a claim now by Aboriginal people that that material should be returned to them-in some cases for burial or in the case of sacred objects just simply returned.

The argument over whether or not that material should be returned is a legitimate function of the Commission and I would see that as a function which the Commission could more properly take on, rather than the Institute, because it is a more political-type body to take on that function. I totally accept Senator Baume's argument that, if we give the Commission that function, then if it does stray into this more sensitive area the sensitivity of that material needs to be protected and therefore I would support the alternative amendment which he has presaged.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I have anything new to add, except in relation to 7 (1) (h). If Senator Baume's intention was that, should the Commission come into possession lawfully of certain materials or information it ought to be aware of the sensitivities of Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders and ensure that no disclosure takes place if secrecy of an absolute kind is required by virtue of the nature of the material, then of course I utterly agree. I have asked the Clerks-maybe Senator Baume has also-to try to draft a clause to that effect, if that is his intention. I may say that I do not think his fear is well founded that the passage of 7 (1) (h) would derogate from those very particular and precise and express words which he inserted into the Institute Bill to ensure the secrecy of the collections of the Institute is maintained. Where there are words dealing expressly with the Institute and its obligations of secrecy, I do not believe a general clause such as this could override those particular secrecy provisions. But, as I say, if Senator Baume's intention is as Senator Coulter and I understand it now, a fall-back position admittedly on his part, and he wishes to exclude 7 (1) (h) in the vote en bloc to deal with that amendment, I would support it.

—Do I understand the Minister to be saying that the best way to proceed might be as follows: that we dispose of the amendments, except for 7 (1) (h), and that we agree to come back to that subclause a little late when the Clerks have had a chance to come back to us? I will just explain, Minister. We might agree to put those words in as a separate subclause somewhere. Then 7 (1) (h) would have to be modified to have somewhere the words `subject to'-whatever the proposed new subclause would be. I therefore suggest that what we do is put 7 (1) (h) aside for a short time and return to it when officers and the Clerks are ready for us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is a fairly simple matter. The words are here. The Clerk at the table can suggest a form of words if they need some minor amendment by the Chair. What Senator Peter Baume really wants in paragraph 7 (1) (h) is:

SPEECH.PARA: The function be discharged in a manner which ensures that the Commission does not disclose information or other matter held by it if that disclosure would be inconsistent with the views or sensitivities of relevant Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders.

That is to adopt the terminology of the Institute Bill, I take it. All I am suggesting is that the honourable senator's amendments (5), (7) and (8) could be dealt with separately and virtually straightaway.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand what the Minister is saying. I really need some guidance now, Mr Temporary Chairman, from your right and left as to the way in which the Clerks think we may proceed. I put to the Minister that, if we divide on the bulk of the amendments, that may provide the Clerks with the 10 minutes or so they require. They can give us the form of words and we can then dispose of those. I am really not terribly fussed. I just do not know what we are voting on at the present moment until I see something.
—The question is that Senator Baume's amendments (2), (3), (4), (6), (9) and (10) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The remaining amendments in this block are (5), (7) and (8). I understand (7) is being redrafted so it comes down to (5) and (8). The question is that amendments (5) and (8) be agreed to.
—Could I ask that further consideration of amendment (7) be deferred for a short time?
—Is the Committee agreeable to deferring consideration of amendment (7)? There being no objection, it is so ordered.
—We now come to block 3 of the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we do, Mr Chairman, I foreshadowed a little earlier that, in the event that our amendments (9) and (10) were unsuccessful, we would try to move that any determination made under clause 8 (2), that is, a power exercised by notice published in the Gazette, should be disallowable. That is simply to ensure that the Parliament should be aware of what is going on and should have at least the capacity to disallow. I therefore move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 8, after subclause 8 (3), add the following new subclause:
``(4) A notice under subsection (2) is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46 (a) of the Acts Interpretation 1901''.

The Committee will understand exactly what the effect of this amendment is. It will not prevent the Government's proceeding to do any of the things it proposes to do with the Bill as it is written. As the Government has not agreed to our amendments, those clauses will stand. But it will ensure that, should any power be exercised under subsection (1) of clause 8 and published in the Gazette, that would be disallowable by the Parliament. This would mean that the concerns that have been expressed to us by some people, that the power could be used improperly, would be allayed in that this would at least make it open to parliamentary scrutiny. Of course, that does not mean that an instrument would be disallowed. It does not mean that people would necessarily move for disallowance. There are thousands of instruments made each year that are potentially disallowable. Honourable senators will know how seldom we seek to exercise that power here. All we are saying is that, since the Government is determined to go this way, we ask that any such determination be a disallowable instrument. That would be the effect of the amendment that I have now moved.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the purpose of clarity I will number the amendment moved by Senator Peter Baume as amendment No. 10a. The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Peter Baume be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government cannot accept this amendment. I have already indicated that we see the way in which this clause would operate as being along the lines of the already existing capacity that the Prime Minister has to make administrative arrangements which can transfer a function from one department to another. The functions provision in section 8 of the current Aboriginal Development Commission Act, which I believe was drafted by the Opposition, says, amongst other things:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . such other functions in connection with the furtherance of the economic and social development of Aboriginals as the Minister determines by notice in writing given to the Commission.

So the legislation drafted by the then Government, now the Opposition, provided a capacity for the Minister to confer further functions that would further the economic and social development of Aboriginals as he determined by writing to the Commission, just by simple notice. The provision that arouses such misgivings, apparently, in the minds of the Opposition is in fact very analogous to that which already exists in the Aboriginal Development Commission Act and which apparently gave no cause for alarm or misgivings at the time it was drafted or presumably in succeeding years to this moment. For that reason the Government cannot agree with this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which section was that?
—Section 8 (g) of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act.

—I rise to support Senator Peter Baume's amendment. I am sure that Senator Coulter will see the common sense of allowing the Senate to review a regulation. It is part of our parliamentary procedures and part of the job of the Senate to review any legislation that comes before it. What Senator Peter Baume is seeking to do is to give the Senate the responsibility to monitor any functions the Prime Minister may wish to change, through his Minister's advice, under this clause. I can see absolutely nothing wrong with giving the Senate that responsibility; in effect, that is what we are here for. The Senate is a House of review, and we are here to review the legislation that comes before the House. I do not think we can support Senator Tate's argument that, because we did not do it when we were in government, therefore it must be wrong. Certainly, one would expect a little more from Senator Tate, who is leading the debate for the Government. Therefore, I ask Senator Coulter to support Senator Peter Baume's amendment.

—I was simply pointing out the fact that the Aboriginal Development Commission legislation was drafted in a way which allowed the Minister to confer functions on the ADC without the need to go through this parliamentary disallowance procedure. I wonder whether-Senator Baume might be able to indicate this-in fact he ever did confer functions on the ADC by notice in writing when he had the august title of Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.
—I say to the Minister that that is a most unfair question.

—I ask the Minister for Justice whether he was saying that the shifting of a function from one government department to the Commission, as would be allowed under this clause, is precisely analogous to what happens when a Prime Minister rearranges the portfolios and redistributes part of a function from one portfolio to another. If that is exactly analogous, then of course that sort of thing goes on the whole time. I suppose, ultimately, the Prime Minister and the Government of which he is a part, are answerable at the following election. That is the mechanism which is used there. But if the process is exactly analogous to that-and that is what I understood his reply to mean-then I have some difficulty in seeing why we should object to this unless we are going to make the redistribution of functions always a process which is disallowable before Parliament. This would, of course, make government almost impossible to work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did mean to convey that. If one reads clause 8 (1) (3) in particular, one sees that the sorts of functions we are talking about are not even as wide as those which were able to be conferred by a Minister for Aboriginal Affairs under the Aboriginal Development Commission Act on the Commission. All that this section permits is the transfer of a function which has previously been performed by a department of state of the Commonwealth. So quite clearly, yes, it is simply a question of transferring to the Commission a function which has been carried out by a particular department.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Postponed amendment No. (7).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I seek leave to withdraw my amendment No. (7).

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment-by leave-withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice might now move his substitute amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move-and it has been circulated to the Committee:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 8, clause 7, after subclause (3) insert the following new subclause:

``(4) In performing its function under paragraph (1) (h), the Commission shall ensure that material or information covered by that paragraph is not disclosed by the Commission if that disclosure would be inconsistent with the views or sensitivities of relevant Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders.''.
I think that is self-explanatory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Justice, the officers and the Clerks for the very expeditious way that this amendment has been produced. This actually meets our concern. Therefore we are more than happy to support it. We thank the Minister for the way in which it has been produced and we wish the amendment a quick acceptance.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the Bill, as amended, be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are several clauses to which I wish to refer very briefly, but to which I do not wish to move any amendments. They are clauses which have appeared as a result of action taken within the Committee, or action taken by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, but in any event action which has led to new clauses being included. I refer first to clause 11, which appears on page 9. I observe that clause 11, which is the clause concerning the corporate plan, did not appear in the 1988 Bill, the first Bill we saw. It has appeared subsequently as a result of Senate inquiries and other concerns, and I am grateful to the Government that this clause has been included as it will result in some improvement in accountability. In the same way clause 24 of the Bill concerns guidelines for the Commission. In the 1988 Bill there was no provision for the publication of guidelines and there is such a provision now; it has been corrected in the 1989 Bill. I note that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee in 1989 has reported on this proposed clause as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: This clause allows the Commission to formulate written guidelines relating to the making of loans to natural persons, and the giving of guarantees in respect of loans given to natural persons.
Subclause (5) requires the Chief Executive officer to give notice of the making of the guidelines in the Gazette.
The opinion of the Committee is that such guidelines should be tabled before Parliament.
That is the view which the Scrutiny of Bills Committee then put to the Minister. The Minister informed the Committee in the following terms:
The Committee has sought an explanation as to why guidelines made pursuant to clause 24 are only required to be published in the Gazette, and not tabled in Parliament.
The primary reason is that these are the Commission's own guidelines, and not the Minister's. The Commission would not be able to make guidelines which are inconsistent with the Act.

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee then thanks the Minister for his response. I have to say to the Committee that I believe the Scrutiny of Bills Committee made a reasonable suggestion, namely, that such guidelines should be tabled before the Parliament. I am disappointed in the response the Minister gave. I am disappointed that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee accepted that explanation but, having said that, it is not the intention of the Opposition to move any frivolous amendments and I do not intend to pursue the matter. However, I want to draw it to the attention of the Committee because it is a matter that gave us some concern.

The third matter to which I wish to refer is clause 25 of the Bill, concerning the review of operation of the Act. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (11) Page 8, paragraph 10 (2) (a), line 35, leave out ``negotiate and''.
(12) Page 8, paragraphs 10 (2) (b) and (c), lines 37 to 40, leave out the paragraphs.
(13) Page 9, subclause 10 (3), lines 2 to 4, leave out the subclause.

These amendments all relate to clause 10 of the Bill. I accept Senator Coulter's point. I was not trying to move out of order but that earlier point seemed to be an appropriate place to mention the other matters I wanted to refer to. Clause 10 of the Bill concerns the powers of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). The three amendments which I have moved together all relate to those powers provided in clause 10. I note that we have already agreed to an amendment by the Government to subclause 10 (2)(a)-we did that last week-so when we are reading clause 10 we must remember that it has already been amended. Subclause (2) of clause 10 gives to the Commission the power to negotiate and cooperate with other Commonwealth bodies and to negotiate with and cooperate with State, Australian Capital Territory, Northern Territory and local government bodies. I ask the Committee to note that that is the first power that is given. Secondly, clause 10 (2) confers a power on ATSIC:
to enter into an agreement for the payment of a grant to a State or the Northern Territory under section 18,
It gives a power to the Commission:
to enter into an agreement (other than an agreement referred to in paragraph (b)) with a State or Territory,

It also gives the Commission certain other powers. The Opposition believes-and I put this to the Committee-that it simply is not appropriate for a statutory body to have the power to negotiate directly with States and Territories about the payment of moneys under section 96 of the Constitution. Moneys that are paid to a State or Territory of the kind referred to here are what we in this place all call section 96 grants. Such activities should be and should remain the responsibility of a Minister who is directly answerable to the Parliament. Section 96 grants are made to the States on such terms and conditions as the Parliament specifies. We know that they are one of the main instruments by which money is transferred from the Federal Government in this country. I remember when I was Minister the States used to love the section 96 grants. They would say to me, `Leave the cheque under the door and go away'. I remember that when Senator Collins was in another legislature we used to discuss this matter sometimes.

The question the Committee has to answer is whether the Parliament is content, or should be content, to delegate to the commissioners of ATSIC the making of whatever arrangements with the States they wish, in the process delegating to the commissioners of ATSIC the power to set, in the name of the Parliament, whatever terms and conditions they like. On our reading of clause 10, as it is written, that is what is proposed. We believe that questions of constitutional propriety come up relating to the difficult interface between this particular Commission-and I accept what the Minister has said about his desire to enhance Aboriginal self-management-and the Parliament and the proper responsibilities of each body. We think that the Government's Bill, with a proposed power for the Commission to deal directly with State governments and to make grants to State governments-section 96 grants-typifies the Government's confusion about the proper role of a statutory authority, on the one hand, and of a department of state on the other. ATSIC is not a department of state. It cannot stand in the place of a department of state, and nor should the States accept such an arrangement. I do not think the States will accept such an arrangement-and then we are going to have a fine old brawl.

Further, this clause relates to the way in which the Commonwealth will deal with the States in matters related to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The Minister did not consult with the States or the Northern Territory on this clause, and at a meeting of the Aboriginal Affairs Ministers at the Australian Aboriginal Affairs Council perhaps a year ago, many of the Ministers made their unhappiness about this known. They are unhappy. The Bill appeared, but on a matter involving relationships between the Commonwealth and the States there was no prior consultation. They told the Minister that they were unhappy and they told him that the arrangement was no good, but there was no acknowledgment of any of that in the second reading speech and nor has there ever been any reasoned response to the concerns which were expressed by State Ministers about provisions like this one.

State Ministers want to deal with the Commonwealth Minister. They wish to deal government to government. Whatever the Minister may say about there being no intention-and he says there is no intention-to vary or even abolish States grants, there is no doubt from our reading of the Bill that the Commission would have the capacity to take action to achieve such a result if it was so minded. Honourable senators may say that it would not be so minded, but the capacity is there. That is what the Bill says. I have to ask the Minister: Is it not true that the fact is that, because there is no obligation on the part of the Commission to enter into agreements with States, it may decide not to do so? What are the States to think about the States grant funding which has been part of the funding of Aboriginal affairs for a long time now, a matter of hard negotiation and accountability? What are the States to think when they read this? As that is written, the States grants could disappear. Subclause 10 (3) is relevant here:
The power of the Commission to enter into agreements of the kind referred to in paragraph 2 (c) shall not be exercised without the written approval of the Minister.

But although that seems to provide some protection, it does not mean that the Minister has to approve the content of any agreement entered into by ATSIC. His approval needs to be obtained only at the threshold. It is approval to enter into an agreement. Read the words. That is what they say. The Commission will need the permission of the Minister to enter into an agreement of the kind referred to in paragraph 2 (c). Those are the words there in proposed clause 10 (3). Once that approval is obtained and once it is then possible for ATSIC to go ahead and carry out that negotiation for which agreement has now been sought and obtained from the Minister, the contents of the agreement will be then something for ATSIC to decide in consultation with the States, and if the Parliament did not like what was proposed, ATSIC could easily decide not to make any further States grants payments or could use the other powers which are conferred on it. Because of those concerns, and again because I genuinely wish to avoid any backlash-I genuinely do not want to provide the kinds of circumstances which will provoke and which will intensify a sense of threat at State level; I do not want to see made more easy a capacity for inflammatory reporting in some of the State and Territory newspapers-because of all that, we have proposed a set of amendments.

Amendment No. 11 seeks to leave out the words `negotiate and' so that if that was done clause 10 (2) (a) would then read `to co-operate with other Commonwealth bodies and with State, Australian Capital Territory, Territory and other local government bodies'. Amendment (12) proposes to leave out paragraphs 2 (b) and 2 (c). We propose to leave those out for the reasons which I have made clear in the arguments I have advanced. We think they relate to States grants type agreements, States grants type functions. We think those are properly matters for government. I can say, perhaps, they are matters for government to undertake on the advice of ATSIC, but they are matters for government to government behaviour. Our amendment (13) proposes that subclause (3) be left out. Subclause (3) is really no protection at all, for reasons which I have already set out in the arguments I have advanced. I commend to the Senate amendments (11), (12) and (13) which have been circulated in my name.

SPEECH.PARA: (a) to negotiate and co-operate with other Commonwealth bodies and with State, Territory and local government bodies;
(b) to enter into an agreement for the payment of a grant to a State or to the Northern Territory under section 18;
(c) to enter into an agreement (other than an agreement referred to in paragraph (b)) with a State or Territory-

We did not write the Australian Constitution. As every honourable senator in the Committee knows, we have had enormous trouble trying to change it. We are simply required to work with it as it is and we are bound by it as it is. What I fear, Minister, is that if grant funding under section 96 were taken from the Federal Government and given direct to the State governments, great animosity would be created, whether we like it or not, and the people who would feel that animosity would be the Aboriginal people. They would feel it because State governments would lose interest. When that hypothetical sewerage system was proposed in Western Australia, the Western Australian Government could say, `Well, that's a Commonwealth responsibility. It has accepted all responsibility for Aboriginals and has just cut us out'. It probably would not be done intentionally but that is what would happen; the Government knows it and I know it.

SPEECH.PARA: In the best interests of Aboriginal people we have got to keep the State governments interested in Aboriginal development because of the responsibilities that they control-land, local government, harbours, marine, fishing, wildlife et cetera. If we treat State governments with contempt-that is what the Government is doing, downgrading all the State and Territory governments of Australia-we will downgrade the Ministers and there will not be Minister to Minister contact. There will be less ministerial council contact. Inevitably-it will happen as surely as night follows day-the State Aboriginal Department, or whatever they call themselves-Community Affairs in Queensland, Aboriginal Affairs, Department of Aboriginal Affairs or whatever they are called-will be downgraded and will be less of a department than they were when they had Minister to Minister contact, and the people who will get hurt are Aboriginal people.

Senator Coulter has picked that up. I know Senator Coulter and I know the Democrats' policy on State governments. He is not one to support them. But the facts are that we have got them there; they are closest to the people, and they have all the equipment. They know what they are doing on the ground, and we are going to remove them by degree out of Aboriginal Affairs. That must be stopped at all costs. Senator Coulter, to his credit, has picked that up, and he deserves congratulations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition's amendments, what we have called group 3, or amendments 11, 12 and 13, relate to the powers of the Commission under clause 10. I would like to reinforce the points made by Senator Peter Baume as to the manner in which any of these agreements that would be structured between ATSIC and either State or Territory governments could be misused. This has to be very carefully read alongside the preamble to the Bill. Whilst I appreciate that will be subject to a later debate in the committee stage, it is important to recognise what the preamble states. Amongst a whole number of other things, it recognises that Aboriginal people were `the prior occupiers and original owners of this land'. It states, `whereas they were dispossessed' and `have no recognised rights over land yet recognised', and, further on, `whereas . . . to reach a lasting and equitable agreement with on the use of their land'. Further on it states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is the firm objective of the people of Australia that policies and programs be maintained and developed by the Governments of the Commonwealth, the States and Territories, that will overcome the economic and social disadvantages of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. . .
. . . it is appropriate to establish measures for the furtherance of the aforementioned objective.

Very clearly, then, the commissioners of ATSIC will see it in the terms of that preamble to the legislation that has been set down, that they will have a responsibility to hold, if necessary to ransom, other levels and forms of government in the negotiations for the financial arrangements which will have to be entered into. That has a direct relationship to national land rights policies.

The Government has not come out and said there will be objectives, but in reading those two alongside each other, what is in the preamble, what are the commitments and the statements and what are the powers that the commissioners will feel that they have with which to direct and look at their own objectives, then it will be incumbent on them. That builds in again the point I was making earlier. That hits the different levels of government and the new Commission directly against the very purposes that we are all seeking to achieve-to improve the lot of Aboriginal people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think we are going to have a vote on this before we adjourn. Do we want to negative the adjournment?
—I do not think so.

—I would just say, in answer to Senator Tambling, that it is a non sequitur in my view and he really should look at clause 3 (d) again, where quite clearly in the objectives clause it is made clear that in furthering the situation of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, there is nothing that should detract from the responsibilities of State, Territory and local government to provide services to their Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. I think one has to keep re-emphasising that: that responsibilities are still very much on the shoulders of those levels of government, constituted as they are under our federal system, and that it is only by agreement with those levels of government that the sort of payments we are talking about under clause 2 (b) can be made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address the Senate tonight on the question of the provision of living areas for Aboriginal people who are living in the direst of circumstances on cattle stations in the Northern Territory. So far as these people are concerned it has often been said, I think principally in the media, that these people were the people whom, `the lands rights Act forgot'. In fact, that is not true. These people were not forgotten by the people who drafted the 1976 Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. They were deliberately excluded from the operations of the Act because the Act specifically provided only for claims to be made on unalienated crown land.

SPEECH.PARA: It was the view of the politicians of the day that as prepared as they were to provide opportunities for Aboriginal people only in the Northern Territory to make claim on unalienated crown land, that is vacant crown land, they were not prepared to extend the ambit of that opportunity beyond unalienated land to land that was alienated. I must say that it would not be difficult to find Aboriginal people who could legitimately lay claim under the same criteria that are used in the land rights Act to almost every square inch in the Northern Territory. It is simply a question of trying to provide opportunities for Aboriginal people to get some redress and justice in this day and age, so late after all of the injustice that has been done to them, in a way that will not frighten the horses or break the bank or do any of those other things. It is the art of the possible, as is often said about politics.

The reason I canvass that is so that people do not forget that what we are talking about now is the provision of areas on land that indeed is alienated and is used for pastoral pursuits and raising cattle. The original position of the parties in this matter, so far as the majority of cattlemen in the Northern Territory was concerned, was that they just wished the whole issue would go away and, from their point of view, one could hardly blame them. Their primary concern was to run a viable cattle property.

So far as the Northern Territory Government was concerned, it was prepared to provide excisions of living areas under existing Northern Territory title for people who were living on cattle stations and no one else. So far as the Northern Territory land councils were concerned, their original position was that they wanted an open ended process applied, utilising Commonwealth procedures, with a Commonwealth tribunal acquiring the land, as it would have been necessary to have acquired it, by compulsory acquisition of the Commonwealth. The reality is that if the people who live in these appalling circumstances on cattle stations ever receive any justice at all, none of these positions can be sustained.

The current position is that after long negotiation a stage has been reached where 95 per cent of the ground between the Northern Territory Government and the Commonwealth Government is common ground. That is the reason I am rising to speak in this debate tonight.

Like most backbenchers speaking in the adjournment debate, I am not speaking on behalf of the Government, I am speaking as a senator for the Northern Territory and as a person who has a personal interest in resolving this problem. When I say that 95 per cent of the ground is common ground I do not want to detract from the seriousness of the issues that still remain to be resolved. The Commonwealth is currently proposing to schedule certain areas of land that are on stock routes and reserves as living areas. The Commonwealth Government wants to schedule these areas as a schedule to the 1976 Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. In other words, they become instantly by a declaration of this Parliament Aboriginal land. The Northern Territory Government wants to deal with these areas of land in the same way as the majority of the excisions, that is, the ones that will be heard by tribunals or simply negotiated directly by consent between the parties.

The Northern Territory Government's position is clear and has merit. The Northern Territory Government is saying, `If the Commonwealth is prepared to accept the amended form of title we are offering on what in effect will be 95 per cent of the cases involved as being sufficient protection for the interests of the Aboriginal people involved, then by inexorable logic the Commonwealth should be prepared to accept that amended form of title as being sufficient protection for all of them'. However, the position is that Aboriginal people, if they pursue the avenues that are still open to them by making land claims over these areas and follow that course to a successful conclusion, are currently in a position where they have a legal right to end up with Commonwealth title at the end of the day. The Commonwealth feels that it is not right to extinguish that position. So the Commonwealth is now determined upon a course, which I support, that says that some of these areas are going to be scheduled.

These areas have grown in number. At the time this matter was negotiated with the then Tuxworth Government there were 11 of these areas, and the number has now grown to 46. I understand that the Minister is currently considering something in excess of 20 of these areas being granted. These areas are subject to Aboriginal land claim, and by scheduling these to the Act the Commonwealth Government, as the Northern Territory Government has pointed out, is circumventing the land claim process. This is true, but I might add that considerable precedent exists for it. When the 1976 Act was enacted very substantial areas of land were simply scheduled, that is, that land involving all of the then existing reserves. However, I believe that there are a number of reasonable pre-conditions for scheduling this land that have to be satisfied by the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Won't that delay the process?

—That is, that the pieces of land that are going to be provided as living areas are fit to live upon, and although that sounds obvious it may not be so obvious. I refer in particular to the existence of potable water supplies. There is very little surface water in most of these areas and in the country in which these areas are located it is often very difficult to find ground water. There is very little point in going through a process of drawing lines on a map and surveying boundaries for living areas if afterwards people are not able to live on them. So I think it is essential that the Commonwealth satisfy itself that these living areas are capable of sustaining life.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth also has to be satisified that they do not detrimentally affect the economic viability of the cattle station as a cattle station. Thirdly, the Commonwealth has to satisfy itself, and indeed others, that people will live on them after they are declared. I say that because I believe that in respect of these scheduled areas the Minister has to be satisfied before the areas are scheduled that the same need criterion which is going to be applied to all of the other excisions that may be granted by the tribunal process is applied to these areas of land that are going to be scheduled as well.

In respect of all of this I believe that once the Commonwealth is satisfied that all these conditions have been met-and, in response to Senator Tambling's earlier interjections, I would hope that these matters have already been resolved-the Commonwealth Government must be in a position to then provide to the Northern Territory Government precise detail of how many of these areas are going to be granted, where they are and what their boundaries are. Now there is a reason for this. The Commonwealth has placed upon the Northern Territory Government deadlines that have to be met in respect of a substantial number of excisions being successfully processed by the Northern Territory Government by a due date. I do not think that is an unreasonable expectation of the Federal Government. However, if the Federal Government is not in a position to provide the Northern Territory Government-and the cattlemen who are directly affected by this-with precise details of how many of these areas are to be scheduled, where they are and what their exact boundaries are, I believe that any deadlines that are placed on the Northern Territory Government to comply similarly are unreasonable from its point of view.

The much vexed question has been raised concerning the proclamation of section 50 of the land rights legislation. The section was inserted by a former Minister, Clyde Holding, and has never been proclaimed. That section of the Act prevents further claims on stock routes and reserves. The Northern Territory Government and indeed the cattlemen have always insisted that this commitment be honoured as a precondition of excisions proceeding. I believe that this matter can be resolved by negotiation and that the solution to the problem is to proclaim this section of the Act at the same time as the living areas that I have just spoken about are scheduled. There remains the far more difficult job of determining those areas of land that are to be set aside for Aboriginals by a process of hearings before a tribunal. The total number of potential excision applications as indicated by the land councils has exceeded 250.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long is that going to take?

—Once the process started I think that the actual number would be much higher. As far as I am concerned-and I have said this publicly on many occasions-the only viable way to proceed is to establish a Northern Territory tribunal to hear these claims. As I have also said publicly on a number of occasions, the basis on which this can be done already exists in the 1984 Aboriginal Community Living Areas Bill that was introduced into the Northern Territory Parliament by the then Chief Minister, Paul Everingham. I stress again that I am not suggesting that the Bill as it stands provides everything that is necessary and does not need to be amended. What I am saying is that it provides a substantial base on which to proceed. Just to indicate briefly to the chamber the sorts of processes that the Bill envisages, the establishment of the tribunal itself would consist of a person being the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court or his nominee, either another judge or a barrister of five years standing in the Northern Territory, and two other persons, one of whom shall be the nominee of the relevant land councils and the other who shall be a nominee of the relevant cattlemen's association. It could not, I think, be fairly said that that is an unreasonable proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I might add, for the benefit of the chamber-not that it is necessary to canvass in detail any more of this Bill-that the majority of the Bill is similarly reasonable and practicable and can be used as a basis on which to proceed with a ready-made framework for the Northern Territory tribunal-again, in response to the interjections from Senator Tambling-to expedite the process as much as we possibly can.

The question of eligibility as a criterion for claim is a very thorny one indeed. In my view these claims can be made only on the threshold eligibility of need. Attached to that should be the addition of the words `historical association'. Indeed the words `historical association' are also found in the 1984 Everingham Bill. I do not believe that it is necessary to include the word `traditional' in the definition of need as a criterion for making claims for two reasons: firstly, because `historical association' covers every possible contingency that I can think of that `traditional' would encompass; and, secondly, because by not using the word `traditional' it removes any emotive connotations of these claims being land claims. I think that in terms of resolving this long-running dispute the removal of any emotive connotations is necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why aren't you the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs?
—Why is Senator Tambling not the Leader of the Opposition? In considering the question of need, the tribunal must have--
—It's much more likely that the former will occur than the latter.

—Thank you very much for your support, Senator. In considering need, the tribunal must have serious regard to the potential of permanent residents. No possibility of weekenders should be entertained, in my view, by the tribunal. If the question is going to be need, as I think there is general agreement now between the Northern Territory Government and the Commonwealth that it needs to be, then the people who are claiming it must be able to demonstrate to the tribunal that they actually intend to permanently reside on the land. If they do not, it will totally destroy the viability and credibility of the process that is entered upon.

SPEECH.PARA: The importance of need is demonstrated-just to give one example-by the situation at Mount Doreen station. This pastoral property is completely surrounded on all of its boundaries by Aboriginal land, but at one time was, in addition, subjected to 15 claims for excisions. The tribunal must also have regard to the same conditions as apply to the areas that the Commonwealth proposes to schedule, and I have already mentioned these. Are the areas of land actually fit to live on? Are they capable of sustaining life? That includes such matters as the size of the block, the existence of potable water supplies, access to the block, and so on; and the detriment to the economic viability of the property concerned must also be considered.

The Northern Territory Government has raised concerns about the land councils acting as agents for the claimants in this process. I do not believe these concerns are sustainable. The land councils are the obvious bodies to act for the claimants and this, in any case, was provided for in clause 15 of the Everingham Bill. Tribunal hearings should be as informal as it is possible to get them, but in full knowledge of the fact that many of them will not be informal-and, indeed, I imagine a number of them will be extremely litigious-I also believe that legal aid should be made available to pastoralists where they can demonstrate that they qualify for it.

After the process under this Northern Territory tribunal is completed, a grant of land should then follow, on a recommendation from the tribunal, by the Northern Territory Minister under the special title which is now being offered by the Northern Territory. That is a form of title which has been uniquely constructed for this particular situation. I believe that it should be possible to consider that, where the Minister has not followed the recommendations of the tribunal, his action should be subject to appeal to some kind of administrative appeals tribunal, or some other appeal process should be provided.

One of the other outstanding areas that need to be resolved is the question of public purpose land on living areas; that is, land that has to be acquired by the Northern Territory Government for public purposes. The Northern Territory Government wants unfettered ability to acquire permanent title under normal conditions under which that is granted. The land councils and, indeed, many Aboriginal people do not. Both sides, once again, have a good argument. The Northern Territory Government sees it as clear cut that where it wants to acquire land for what is often the benefit of the community itself, such as a school or a health clinic, there should be no bar to its simply going ahead and doing it. On the other side of the argument, the Aboriginal people concerned are rightly suspicious and distrustful-not, I hasten to say, because of any particular distrust or dislike they may have for the actions of this current Government. They have a very legitimate distrust for the generations of abuse and injustice that have been dealt out to them and their forebears. It is impossible to put that legitimate sense of grievance and distrust aside, and I do not think it should be put aside. Therefore, I believe that a middle course is appropriate.

Consent agreements between the land councils and the Northern Territory Government would provide for speedy resolution of 90 per cent or more of the cases for leases for schools, health clinics or other obvious public purposes that benefit the community directly. Where agreement cannot be reached the matter should be able to be referred by either party to the Northern Territory tribunal, the one that I just discussed. In this case, the tribunal would have to be provided, in my view, with a determinant, rather than a recommended, capacity.

The question then also goes to what kind of title is provided to the Northern Territory Government. The Territory Government wants a form of title which permanently alienates the land for the public purpose. I do not believe, having spoken to people who know far more about the legal complexities of title than I do, that this is required at all. In fact, I have been satisfied that a lesser form of title which did not provide for permanent alienation to the Northern Territory Government for public purpose land would be sufficient for the purposes for which land would ever be acquired for public purpose by the Northern Territory Government.

We move, finally, to what is a serious matter of issue between the Northern Territory Government and the Commonwealth Government, and that is the question of entrenchment in Commonwealth law of the conditions under which these titles will be granted, such entrenchment provisions being triggered by the perceived failure-or proven failure-of the Northern Territory Government to honour its undertakings. Once again, I can understand these entrenchment provisions being demanded in order for the Commonwealth to demonstrate to the Aboriginal people concerned and indeed to the world at large that it is very serious indeed about resolving this question quickly, which it is. However, the Northern Territory Government finds that this condition being held over its head prior to the detailed negotiations proceeding is highly offensive and in fact inimical to the proper process of negotiation.

Whilst I have no difficulty in supporting such a proposal I do believe that the proposal is very much an indication of the current stage of the negotiations between the Northern Territory Government and the Commonwealth and I hope that it will not be necessary to insist upon it. The reason I am speaking in the adjournment debate tonight, in fact, is that I have been advised today that the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory has been assisted in coming to Canberra this week, I understand on Wednesday, to have discussions with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in an attempt to get down to the nuts and bolts of resolving this issue in the interests of the people who have been so long neglected. I believe, Mr President, that if these negotiations are conducted in the spirit in which I hope they will be substantial agreement should be reached between the two governments on those small areas where conflict still exists. If that substantial agreement is reached, I do not believe it should be necessary to proceed with this entrenchment proposal by the Commonwealth.

The political reality, of course, is that if the Northern Territory reneges on any of the undertakings that it has given, which I personally do not believe it will, legislation to redress that situation could be very quickly introduced into this Parliament. I do not think the Australian Democrats would be too offended if I suggested that, if it were introduced because of a failure of the Northern Territory Government to honour its commitments to Aboriginal people, the Democrats would assist its being given speedy passage through both Houses of the Parliament. Therefore, I do not think that the necessity should exist for those provisions to be placed in the legislation now. I think that a far more appropriate proposal that should, in fact, be substituted in its place is a memorandum of understanding or heads of agreement detailing all of the agreed positions of the two governments and the obligations of the two governments and signed by both the Prime Minister and the Chief Minister.

We also have to consider, I think, what the alternative is to such a negotiated agreement on the basis that I have suggested. I believe that what I have laid out-and I might add that I think it substantially complies with what both governments have already indicated they are prepared to do anyway-provides a fair and reasonable base for this matter to be finally resolved with justice for all of the parties concerned. The alternative to this negotiated process would be a process of compulsory acquisition by the Commonwealth Government of potentially hundreds of areas across the Northern Territory. I believe this would have horrendous consequences, including financially for the Commonwealth Government. It would have enormously beneficial effects for the legal fraternity, of course, once again. But of course millions of dollars would be spent on legal challenges both the claims themselves and to the compensation payments that would result-not to mention the political agenda that would be sparked off by what would be a prolonged and very bitter period of acrimony and legal dispute. But the major casualty in all of that exercise, Mr President, would be once again the Aboriginal people who are living on cattle stations and who have missed out for so long. I believe that under this process they would miss out again for perhaps another decade.

In conclusion, I would like to say not as a senator of the Northern Territory, a member of the Government or of the Labor Party or anything else but simply as someone who has personally witnessed the appalling conditions under which these most deprived Australians live, that I hope that the discussions that will be held this week are held on the basis of mutual trust between the two governments concerned with a common desire to solve this problem to the benefit of the people who are most detrimentally affected by the existing situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —One in five men responding to a survey commissioned by the Office of the Status of Women condoned the use of violence by a man against his partner. `It's okay to slap the little woman about a bit' must rank among the most pervasive of Australian myths, along with that other myth that domestic violence is a private matter. The shield of privacy must be stripped away from the perpetrators of actions which, if they occurred outside the home, would be condemned as criminal behaviour.

SPEECH.PARA: The plight of any victim of domestic violence is great but for a woman of non-English speaking background married to an Australian it is appalling. A number of Filipino women, apparently perceived by some Australian men as compliant, acquiescent and subservient wife material, are brought to Australia as brides or fiances and find themselves in difficulties when their Australian husbands use violence against them.

These women are frequently isolated in society without family support: isolated by lack of language skills; by culture; by education; and occasionally by location in country or rural areas. However, many of these women are considerably better educated than their husbands and they speak English very well. Filipino-Australian marriages are likely to be as successful as marriages generally. They could well have a lower rate of breakdown, given that divorce or separation is not as acceptable to a Filipino woman because of her culture and religion.

When a marriage breakdown is precipitated by so-called domestic violence a Filipino woman experiences great personal and social trauma, especially if her Australian husband threatens her with divorce and deportation. The Philippine-Australian Council in Support of Filipino Women has raised a number of particular cases, two of which I will describe here. The first relates to a Filipino woman with a 15-month-old son, who has been in Australia for three years on a fiance visa. She is in a de facto relationship with the same man who nominated her and who refuses to marry her because he claims she cannot get along with his mother. He set the date for their wedding four times and four times he changed his mind. Every time she told him she would leave him, he told her he would have her deported. She is scared for herself and her baby's health because she cannot get a Medicare or health card from the Department of Social Security.

In the second case a Filipino woman in her early thirties was asked by her husband to leave him because he said that he would have more money as a single person on a pension-he is a handicapped person-than having a family to support, with a family pension. She left her husband after endless arguments and fights and went to live with a friend while waiting for her application for housing. In both cases the Council was able to help the women.

There have been many instances when Filipino women have returned to violent husbands because of these threats, because of their own isolation and because such husbands have had the protection of privacy. The same council-the Philippine-Australian Council in Support of Filipino Women-has identified some instances. In these cases two Filipino women with two children each were victims of domestic physical violence. Both left their homes with their children and were taken in at a women's refuge, but both went back to their husbands due to problems that they encountered in the refuge. In another case, a Filipino woman repeatedly abused by her husband left him to stay with a friend. She had to go back to him because of the lack of support from her friend, and also because she was afraid to live alone.

Few of these women avail themselves of services that may help and protect them. This could be because they are unaware that the services exist or because the husband has so isolated the woman socially that she is totally dependent on him. When a Filipino woman does approach the bureaucracy of our agencies and social services she often finds that the staff lack sensitivity to her own particular dilemma, not because they are unfeeling but because they have little or no appreciation of the utter dependency of these women on their husbands or of their difficulties with the language. Although they speak English and speak it well, many of them have difficulty understanding the Australian vernacular. It takes a woman of great resolve to make a break with what little security she has in her marriage and face almost inevitable deprivation, humiliation and possible deportation. I would like to outline the case of one such woman.

In August 1988 Willy Rohrbacher, aged 57, married Susana, aged 30, in the Catholic Church at Grafton. He had met his bride when she came to Australia to visit her sister, a friend of his adult daughter who is only four years younger than Susana. When Rohrbacher was introduced to Susana, and hearing that she was a registered midwife in the Philippines and therefore a professional and capable of earning money, he immediately bought an engagement and wedding ring and proposed on the spot. Susana was not on the bride market and was not prepared to grab what might have appeared to be an opportunity to set herself up in this country with house and husband. She put off the decision for three months.

After her marriage Susana became Rohrbacher's housekeeper, nurse and chauffeur since her husband was unable to drive. I believe she also tried to teach him English since he was not able to read or write English. She cleared land and mowed the lawns on his large block of land at Grafton while attending the technical and further education (TAFE) computer data processing advanced certificate course to prepare herself for employment. Her husband had made it clear to her that he expected to recover all the expenses that he had incurred since the wedding. Meanwhile he gave her sufficient money only to buy food. He then forced her to apply for a job as a cleaner at the Grafton Base Hospital, clearly a job that was considerably below her expectations and training.

A letter from Susana's godparents, Valma and Charles Burke, both justices of the peace, describes how Rohrbacher treated his newly wedded wife. In a letter to the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs they wrote:
She wasn't allowed to read her Bible which is very important to a catholic Filipina. He tried stopping her from going to church on Sunday mornings. Several times I-
that is, Valma Burke-

had rang her and he would be shouting and abusing her in the background while I spoke to her. He would not allow her to come to the Filipina gatherings as they will all come together once a month as a family group and have a barbecue and have a lovely day, singing and talking and playing with the children.

Early this year Rohrbacher started beating Susana, hitting her repeatedly on the head. He threatened that if she kept answering him back he would make her a cripple. In May she received a serious beating and sustained severe head injuries. She was admitted to the Grafton Base Hospital on this occasion, complaining of severe headache, dizziness, nausea and vomiting and later was transferred to the neurosurgical ward for examination and kept there for three days. Whilst she was in the hospital she decided not to return home but to go to the Grafton women's refuge. When he discovered this, Rohrbacher harassed her in front of other patients and on the phone. Although a restraining order had been granted on 17 May, he went to the TAFE college and verbally abused her in front of her fellow students in the class.

Although the application for the restraining order had in itself caused Susana much distress because of her views on marriage, she decided nonetheless to leave her husband. She left without money, she left without the right to be employed in order to keep herself, and she left knowing that her husband's threat to have her deported could be realised. In response Rohrbacher withdrew his sponsorship for Susana's application for resident status. Had Rohrbacher been able to batter her into being a subservient, socially inept and isolated wife he might not have withdrawn his sponsorship.

I was told of Susana's dreadful situation after visiting the women's refuge at Grafton several weeks ago. I informed the social workers of the Filipino community and welfare services of her plight and they subsequently assisted her in finding accommodation out of Grafton and out of the reach of her violent husband. She now waits in Sydney in hope of a favourable consideration of her application for resident status. She does not want to violate restrictions on obtaining paid employment and so has no way of supporting herself. In the meantime she lives on special benefits of about $120 per week and pays $60 a week to share accommodation with another woman. She still requires medical care for the effects of her injuries but has no Medicare card and no money to pay for medical treatment. She had to discontinue her studies when she left Grafton but she has already commenced another computer course. She told me this evening she was the top student in her midwifery course in the Philippines but now her memory has been very badly affected by the beatings she has received. I believe that if she were to be allowed to stay in Australia she would make a valuable and positive contribution to the community.

There are, however, for many women like Susana real difficulties if they contemplate returning to the Philippines. The Burkes describe the situation in the same letter to the immigration department. Filipinas will put up with more abuse and assault than Australian women to try to save the marriage and save face, as their marriage is very sacred. If this little Filipina is deported, she would rather end her life than go back to her country after getting married. She would be disgraced and would lose face and faith. She would rather die than go home and face her family disgraced. This is a well known fact. Please give her case very careful consideration as there are two sides to this story.
